Colliers: Dallas Gears Up to Host 2026 FIFA World Cup, A Game-Changing Moment for Real Estate and Economic Growth
Source: citybiz    Published: 2025-08-27 18:22:07

Colliers is pleased to announce the release of its Dallas-Fort Worth metro report,‚ÄØFrom Stadiums to Skylines: Real Estate Trends in World Cup Host Cities, showcasing the direct impact the FIFA Men's World Cup will have on the market through the lens of real estate and economic development. With the city hosting nine matches at AT&T Stadium, including a semi-final, the sporting event is expected to bring 2.7 million visitors to the region and generate an estimated $2.1 billion for its economy. ‚ÄúThis is an exciting time for soccer fans and the city as a whole,‚Äù said Texas Region Executive Managing Director Daniel Taylor. ‚ÄØThis event represents far more than world-class soccer‚Äîit's an opportunity to highlight Dallas' progress, strength and welcoming spirit. Colliers'‚ÄØFrom Stadiums to Skylines‚ÄØreport provides critical insights into how the World Cup will shape our local economy and real estate landscape, underscoring Dallas' readiness and long-term potential as a powerhouse market.‚Äù Key Findings from the Report Include: Multifamily stability. Dallas-Fort Worth ranks number one in the U.S. for real estate investment and development in 2025, driven by strong population growth, over 50,000 multifamily units under construction, top-three net migration, resilient workforce housing rents, investor confidence and solid submarket performance. Strong office presence. The Dallas-Fort Worth area continues to attract investment due to its affordability, accessibility, and robust economy. As of Q2 2025, more than 4 million square feet of office space is under construction, led by financial services, tech, and professional sectors. Demand is strong in key submarkets such as Uptown Dallas, Preston Center, Fort Worth CBD, Las Colinas and Far North Dallas, where companies are gravitating toward Class A, mixed-use buildings. Global industrial hub. Dallas-Fort Worth is one of the top three industrial markets in the U.S., with over 1 billion square feet of space and more than 80 buildings larger than 1 million square feet, up from just eight in 2000. Since 2020, over 80 million square feet have been delivered, with development continuing to meet strong demand. DFW's location allows same-day access to 93 percent of the Texas population and next-day delivery to much of the U.S., supported by low taxes and a large, affordable labor pool. Vacancy rates declined to 9.3 percent in the second quarter of 2025, down from 9.8 percent in the first quarter. ‚ÄúHosting the 2026 FIFA Men's World Cup is an opportunity for Dallas to demonstrate its economic strength, world-class infrastructure, and dynamic culture to a global audience,‚Äù said Marianne Skorupski, Director of National Office Research at Colliers. ‚ÄúThis event will further reinforce Dallas' global standing and drive lasting momentum across its real estate and business landscape.‚Äù Sports and Entertainment Arena The Dallas region boasts a rich legacy in sports and entertainment, partially anchored by Arlington's Entertainment District, a premier destination that draws over 15.6 million visitors annually and generates $2.8 billion in economic impact. This transformation is the result of strategic planning, public-private partnerships and a long-term vision to create a vibrant, walkable urban hub. Renowned venues in the district include AT&T Stadium (home of the Dallas Cowboys), Globe Life Field (Texas Rangers), Choctaw Stadium, Six Flags Over Texas and Six Flags Hurricane Harbor. Texas Live!, a dynamic entertainment complex, adds to the district's appeal with dining, nightlife, and year-round live events. The region also has a deep connection to soccer, dating back to 1967 when the United Soccer Association brought professional soccer to Texas. Dallas hosted the FIFA World Cup in 1994, and its return in 2026 is projected to generate an even greater economic impact, expected to exceed the $600 million mark set three decades ago. Download the report here About‚Äã Colliers Colliers is a global diversified professional services and investment management company. Operating through three industry-leading platforms ‚Äì Real Estate Services, Engineering, and Investment Management ‚Äì we have a proven business model, an enterprising culture, and a unique partnership philosophy that drives growth and value creation. For 30 years, Colliers has consistently delivered approximately 20% compound annual returns for shareholders, fueled by visionary leadership, significant inside ownership and substantial recurring earnings. With nearly $5.0 billion in annual revenues, a team of 23,000 professionals, and more than $100 billion in assets under management, Colliers remains committed to accelerating the success of our clients, investors, and people worldwide. Learn more at corporate.colliers.com, X @Colliers or LinkedIn. ¬© Copyright 2012 - 2023 | citybiz | All Rights Reserved

Bayern Munich reportedly eyeing World Cup-winning forward to challenge Harry Kane
Source: World Soccer Talk    Published: 2025-08-27 18:06:15

connect with us By Francisco Quatrin Updated on August 27, 2025 Harry Kane has been one of the most lethal scorers in world soccer over the past decade. The English striker wrote history with Tottenham Hotspur, becoming their all-time leading scorer and climbing to second on the Premier League's all-time list. With the England national team, he is both captain and the country's top scorer. Since moving to Bayern Munich in 2023, Kane has continued his extraordinary form, finding the net relentlessly in Germany. Now 32 years old, Kane remains at the top of his game. His numbers with Bayern are staggering: 89 goals and 26 assists in 98 appearances since his arrival. Yet, as dominant as he has been, Bayern faces the reality of relying too heavily on him. The Bavarians have often lacked a reliable alternative whenever Kane was unavailable or not at his best, leading to costly eliminations in competitions like the Champions League and the Club World Cup. To address this issue, Bayern has turned its attention to Nicolas Jackson, the 23-year-old Senegalese forward currently with Chelsea. Jackson was a regular starter for the Blues last season but has since lost ground. With the arrivals of Jo√£o Pedro and Liam Delap, his minutes have decreased, and he now finds himself battling for playing time in London. Chelsea striker Nicolas Jackson. According to transfer reports, including updates from insider Fabrizio Romano, Bayern and Chelsea are in direct talks regarding a deal. The discussion centers on the structure of the transfer, as Chelsea only has one remaining international loan slot available and insists on including a mandatory purchase clause. While no agreement has been finalized, Bayern continues to push for the move. see also Cristiano Ronaldo vs. Kingsley Coman: Legend's $244M salary compared to Al Nassr's new Bayern signing For Bayern, Jackson offers both short-term relief for Kane and long-term potential. His pace, physicality, and ability to stretch defenses could provide a different attacking dimension, especially in domestic matches where Kane may need rest. At 23, Jackson still has room to grow, and working alongside Kane could accelerate his development. The club's recent struggles without Kane underline the urgency of the signing. When their star striker is neutralized or absent, Bayern's attack has often looked one-dimensional. Bringing in Jackson would not only give Kane valuable rest but also ensure that Bayern can remain competitive across multiple competitions. Includes: Premier League + 84 Sports Channels Includes: Bundesliga & La Liga Includes: Champions League & Serie A Includes: Premier League Includes: every MLS game and Leagues Cup Bayern Munich star Harry Kane praised Lamine Yamal and even imagined a potential showdown against Barcelona in the UEFA Champions League. Luis Diaz made a blockbuster move to Bayern Munich, and comparisons didn't doubt to raise regarding his new deal and star's Harry Kane $29 million salary. Harry Kane will not start for Bayern Munich in today's Group C finale against Benfica at the 2025 FIFA Club World Cup. Though not injured, Kane is being rested by head coach Vincent Kompany, likely to preserve him for the knockout stages. Inter Miami face Orlando City SC in the 2025 Leagues Cup semifinals. Bayern Munich eyeing World Cup-winning forward to challenge Harry Kane
Source: World Soccer Talk    Published: 2025-08-27 18:06:15

by Francisco Quatrin August 27, 2025 Harry Kane has been one of the most lethal scorers in world soccer over the past decade. The English striker wrote history with Tottenham Hotspur, becoming their all-time leading scorer and climbing to second on the Premier League's all-time list. With the England national team, he is both captain and the country's top scorer. Since moving to Bayern Munich in 2023, Kane has continued his extraordinary form, finding the net relentlessly in Germany. Now 32 years old, Kane remains at the top of his game. His numbers with Bayern are staggering: 89 goals and 26 assists in 98 appearances since his arrival. Yet, as dominant as he has been, Bayern faces the reality of relying too heavily on him. The Bavarians have often lacked a reliable alternative whenever Kane was unavailable or not at his best, leading to costly eliminations in competitions like the Champions League and the Club World Cup. To address this issue, Bayern has turned its attention to Nicolas Jackson, the 23-year-old Senegalese forward currently with Chelsea. Jackson was a regular starter for the Blues last season but has since lost ground. With the arrivals of Jo√£o Pedro and Liam Delap, his minutes have decreased, and he now finds himself battling for playing time in London. According to transfer reports, including updates from insider Fabrizio Romano, Bayern and Chelsea are in direct talks regarding a deal. The discussion centers on the structure of the transfer, as Chelsea only has one remaining international loan slot available and insists on including a mandatory purchase clause. While no agreement has been finalized, Bayern continues to push for the move. see also Cristiano Ronaldo vs. Kingsley Coman: Legend's $244M salary compared to Al Nassr's new Bayern signing For Bayern, Jackson offers both short-term relief for Kane and long-term potential. His pace, physicality, and ability to stretch defenses could provide a different attacking dimension, especially in domestic matches where Kane may need rest. At 23, Jackson still has room to grow, and working alongside Kane could accelerate his development. The club's recent struggles without Kane underline the urgency of the signing. When their star striker is neutralized or absent, Bayern's attack has often looked one-dimensional. Bringing in Jackson would not only give Kane valuable rest but also ensure that Bayern can remain competitive across multiple competitions. Academy's Jamir Johnson named to U.S Under-17 Men's National Team
Source: Philadelphia Union    Published: 2025-08-27 17:52:46

Philadelphia Union announced today that Academy forward Jamir Johnson has been selected to join the U.S. Under-17 Men's National Team training camp. Head coach Gonzalo Segares called up 21 players for the international training camp, which will take place from Sept. 1-8 in Noordwijk, Netherlands. Johnson is joined by Union homegrown midfielder Cavan Sullivan as well as Union II midfielder Kellan LeBlanc for the camp next month. This marks the third call-up to the U-17s for Johnson, who has made five appearances and tallied three goals and two assists. The camp is part of the Federation's continued focus on the U.S. Way philosophy, which emphasizes increased programming for Youth National Teams to create more opportunities for young players to advance through the pathway to the senior National Team with the goal of representing their country at a world championship. In the team's second-to-last gathering before heading to the 2025 FIFA U-17 World Cup in Qatar, Segares will guide the U-17 MNT in a pair of friendly matches against the Netherlands on Sept. 5 and Sept. 8 at Gemeentelijk Sportpark SJC in Noordwijk, Netherlands. Both matches will kick off at 7 p.m. local time (1 p.m. ET). All players are born after Jan. 1, 2008, and are age-eligible for this fall's FIFA U-17 World Cup, where the USA will face Burkina Faso (Nov. 5), Tajikistan (Nov. 8) and Czechia (Nov. 11) in Group I. The roster features 16 players from 10 different Major League Soccer clubs. The LA Galaxy and Philadelphia Union lead the way with three players each, followed by New York Red Bulls and Real Salt Lake with two selections each, while Atlanta United, Charlotte, Columbus Crew, LAFC, New York City FC and Sporting Kansas City round out the roster with one selection apiece. Following this month's matches in the Netherlands, the U-17 MNT will meet once more during the October FIFA window before Segares names his roster for Qatar. GOALKEEPERS (2): William Lomdell (Sporting Lisbon/POR; Lisbon, Portugal), Aidan Stokes (New York Red Bulls; Totowa, N.J.) DEFENDERS (7): Pedro Guimaraes (Orange County SC; Aliso Viejo, Calif.), Ramiz Hamouda (Birmingham Legion; Lincoln, Neb.), Ryan Hartley (LA Galaxy; Manhattan Beach, Calif.), Ian James (Sporting Kansas City; St. Paul, Minn.), Enrique Martinez (LA Galaxy; Compton, Calif.), Oliver Tan (Pacos de Ferreira/POR; Piedmont, Calif.), Gio Villa (Real Salt Lake; Chicago, Ill.) MIDFIELDERS (7): M√°ximo Carrizo (New York City FC; Greenwich, Conn.), Kellan LeBlanc (Philadelphia Union; Royersford, Pa.), Luca Moisa (Real Salt Lake; Las Vegas, Nev.), Cooper Sanchez (Atlanta United; Holly Springs, Ga.), Cavan Sullivan (Philadelphia Union; Philadelphia, Pa.), Jude Terry (LAFC; San Diego, Calif.), Mateo Tsakiris (LA Galaxy; Saratoga, Calif.) FORWARDS (5): Chase Adams (Columbus Crew; Naperville, Ill.), Mathis Albert (Borussia Dortmund/GER; El Segundo, Calif.), Nimfasha Berchimas (Charlotte FC; High Point, N.C.), Julian Hall (New York Red Bulls; New York, N.Y.), Jamir Johnson (Philadelphia Union; Huntsville, Ala.)

Homegrown Cavan Sullivan named to U.S Under-17 Men's National Team
Source: Philadelphia Union    Published: 2025-08-27 17:50:45

Philadelphia Union announced today that Homegrown midfielder Cavan Sullivan has been selected to join the U.S. Under-17 Men's National Team training camp. Head coach Gonzalo Segares called up 21 players for the international training camp, which will take place from Sept. 1-8 in Noordwijk, Netherlands. Sullivan is joined by Union II midfielder Kellan LeBlanc, and Academy forward Jamir Johnson for the camp next month. This marks the third call-up to the U-17s for the homegrown midfielder with Sullivan having made six appearances for the team, scoring one goal. The camp is part of the Federation's continued focus on the U.S. Way philosophy, which emphasizes increased programming for Youth National Teams to create more opportunities for young players to advance through the pathway to the senior National Team with the goal of representing their country at a world championship. In the team's second-to-last gathering before heading to the 2025 FIFA U-17 World Cup in Qatar, Segares will guide the U-17 MNT in a pair of friendly matches against the Netherlands on Sept. 5 and Sept. 8 at Gemeentelijk Sportpark SJC in Noordwijk, Netherlands. Both matches will kick off at 7 p.m. local time (1 p.m. ET). All players are born after Jan. 1, 2008, and are age-eligible for this fall's FIFA U-17 World Cup, where the USA will face Burkina Faso (Nov. 5), Tajikistan (Nov. 8) and Czechia (Nov. 11) in Group I. The roster features 16 players from 10 different Major League Soccer clubs. The LA Galaxy and Philadelphia Union lead the way with three players each, followed by New York Red Bulls and Real Salt Lake with two selections each, while Atlanta United, Charlotte, Columbus Crew, LAFC, New York City FC and Sporting Kansas City round out the roster with one selection apiece. Following this month's matches in the Netherlands, the U-17 MNT will meet once more during the October FIFA window before Segares names his roster for Qatar. GOALKEEPERS (2): William Lomdell (Sporting Lisbon/POR; Lisbon, Portugal), Aidan Stokes (New York Red Bulls; Totowa, N.J.) Three LA Galaxy Academy Products Called Up for U.S. U-17 Men's National Team Roster for Friendlies in Netherlands
Source: LA Galaxy    Published: 2025-08-27 17:03:50

LA Galaxy Academy products Ryan Hartley, Kike Martinez and Mateo Tsakiris each named to U-17 USMNT roster for international training camp in Netherlands from Sept. 1-8 LOS ANGELES (Wednesday, Aug. 27, 2025) ‚Äì LA Galaxy Academy products Ryan Hartley, Enrique ‚ÄúKike‚Äù Martinez and Mateo Tsakiris were each named to the U.S. U-17 Men's National Team roster for an international training camp to be held in Noordwijk, Netherlands from Sept. 1-8. The camp is part of the Federation's continued focus on the U.S. Way philosophy, which emphasizes increased programming for Youth National Teams to create more opportunities for young players to advance through the pathway to the senior National Team with the goal of representing their country at a world championship. The roster features 16 players from 10 different Major League Soccer clubs. The LA Galaxy and Philadelphia Union lead the way with three players each. In the team's second-to-last gathering before heading to the 2025 FIFA U-17 World Cup in Qatar, Segares will guide the U-17 MNT in a pair of friendly matches against the Netherlands on Friday, Sept. 5 and Monday, Sept. 8 at Gemeentelijk Sportpark SJC in Noordwijk, Netherlands. Both matches will kick off at 7:00 p.m. local time (10:00 a.m. PT). All players are born after Jan. 1, 2008, and are age-eligible for this fall's FIFA U-17 World Cup, where the USA will face Burkina Faso (Nov. 5), Tajikistan (Nov. 8) and Czechia (Nov. 11) in Group I. Ian James to join United States U-17 Men's National Team for Netherlands training camp
Source: Sporting Kansas City    Published: 2025-08-27 17:02:19

Sporting Kansas City defender Ian James has been selected to the United States U-17 Men's National Team for a training camp from Sept. 1-8 in Noordwijk, Netherlands. Led by head coach Gonzalo Segares, the United States will face the Netherlands U-17s in a pair of friendlies kicking off at 12 p.m. CT on Sept. 5 and Sept. 8 at Gemeentelijk Sportpark SJC. The matches will serve as valuable tune-ups as the U.S. U-17s continue their preparations for the 2025 FIFA U-17 World Cup in Qatar, where the United States will face Burkina Faso (Nov. 5), Tajikistan (Nov. 8) and Czechia (Nov. 11) in Group I. James, a 17-year-old center back who joined Sporting's first team ahead of the 2025 MLS campaign, previously competed with the U.S. U-17s during a training camp in Costa Rica in March. The 6-foot-2 defender broke into the U-17 national team last November by participating in a camp in West Palm Beach, Florida. On Feb. 25, James became the second-youngest player in Sporting history to appear in a competitive match by featuring in a Concacaf Champions Cup loss at Inter Miami CF. At 16 years and 264 days, he etched his name as only the second 16-year-old to take the field for Sporting KC, following in the footsteps of Academy product Gianluca Busio who first did so in 2018. James made the first three appearances of his MLS career earlier this summer, a stretch that saw Sporting collect seven of a possible nine points. He earned his league debut on June 25, helping the team close out a dramatic 2-1 home win over Charlotte FC. He earned his first start three days later by going the full 90 minutes in a 1-1 home draw with Real Salt Lake, becoming the second youngest starter in an MLS match in club history at 17 years and 22 days. On July 4, he played the entire second half of a 2-1 road victory over the Colorado Rapids. James most recently appeared as a second-half substitute on Sunday at Seattle Sounders FC. In addition to playing five first-team matches this season, James has started in eight MLS NEXT Pro games for Sporting KC II. On Dec. 6, 2024, James became the fourth youngest player in club history and the youngest defender signed to an MLS contract when he inked a Homegrown deal alongside teammate and goalkeeper Jack Kortkamp. He has represented Sporting at the U-14 through U-19 youth levels since joining the Academy in 2021 and notably competed in the 2024 MLS NEXT All-Star Game last summer in Columbus, Ohio. Sporting will return to Children's Mercy Park on Saturday, hosting Colorado at 7:30 p.m. CT with tickets available at SeatGeek.com and live coverage on MLS Season Pass via Apple TV.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


FIFA review could be great news for Chelsea after Todd Boehly's big ¬£85m win
Source: The Chelsea Chronicle    Published: 2025-08-27 17:00:00

Not everyone was a fan of this summer's Club World Cup, but Chelsea and Todd Boehly certainly were. Under Enzo Maresca, Chelsea were able to win the tournament and earn a huge amount of cash in the process. Despite beating Paris Saint-Germain in the final, the champions of Europe, the Blues are not getting carried away. It is thought that Chelsea's goal for the new season is still just Champions League qualification. As things stand, Chelsea would need to win that very competition in the next four years to guarantee a place in the 2029 Club World Cup. According to the Daily Mail, Gianni Infantino and the rest of FIFA are currently in the process of reviewing how to make the Club World Cup even better. Their review includes deciding whether Chelsea should be invited back to defend their trophy, meaning that the Blues may not need to rely on winning the Champions League or their UEFA coefficient after all. That would be great news for Boehly and Behdad Eghbali, who will want the club to compete in the tournament's next edition after all of the money that was won this year. Chelsea üÜö PSG#FIFACWC pic.twitter.com/FfB5cdxffZ As per Sky Sports, Chelsea took home ¬£85m after managing to win the whole thing in the US last month. Playing all of those extra games may have an impact on Chelsea's squad. Injury expert Ben Dinnery has told The Chelsea Chronicle that supporters may not see the best of Chelsea until November or December because of their participation at the Club World Cup. At the end of the day, though, the money was too good to turn down and it will be exactly the same case in 2029. One reason why Chelsea were able to lift the Club World Cup trophy was because of Joao Pedro. Pedro arrived from Brighton & Hove Albion midway through the competition and scored in the semi-finals and the final. Pedro earned ¬£350,000 for his contribution, as did the rest of the Chelsea team. The Brazilian definitely deserved his reward.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Christian Pulisic returns, Weston McKennie snubbed from USMNT squad; Champions League playoffs conclude
Source: CBS Sports    Published: 2025-08-27 15:55:59

If not listed, please contact your TV provider. Hello! UEFA Champions League qualifiers wrap up on Wednesday ahead of Thursday's draw but even as the club game takes center stage, the U.S. men's national team are already gearing up for September's international break. I'm Pardeep Cattry with the latest. All times U.S./Eastern Wednesday, Aug. 27üá™üá∫ UCL qualification: Qarabag vs. Ferencvaros 12:45 p.m. ‚û°Ô∏è Paramount+üá™üá∫ UCL qualification: Benfica vs. Fenerbahce, 3 p.m. ‚û°Ô∏è Paramount+üá™üá∫ UCL qualification: Copenhagen vs. Basel, 3 p.m. ‚û°Ô∏è Paramount+üá™üá∫ UCL qualification: Club Brugge vs. Rangers, 3 p.m. ‚û°Ô∏è Paramount+üè¥Û†ÅßÛ†Å¢Û†Å•Û†ÅÆÛ†ÅßÛ†Åø EFL Cup: Grimsby Town vs. Man United, 3 p.m. ‚û°Ô∏è Paramount+üá∫üá∏ Leagues Cup: Inter Miami vs. Orlando City, 8:30 p.m. ‚û°Ô∏è MLS Season Pass Thursday, Aug. 28üá™üá∫ UCL draw, 12 p.m. ‚û°Ô∏è Paramount+ U.S. men's national team head coach Mauricio Pochettino is once again leaning on a group of lesser known talent, calling up a group of inexperienced players for September's friendlies against South Korea and Japan, a camp he describes as "the last opportunity to bring some new faces" with less than 300 days to go until the 2026 World Cup. Take a look at the roster below. Only seven players in the squad have 30-plus caps, while 11 members from this summer's Concacaf Gold Cup roster return and five could earn their first cap next month. September's friendlies will see Christian Pulisic's return after a summer of bickering between USMNT players past and present following the player's decision to opt out of the Gold Cup, a chapter Pochettino said was "behind us" with months to go until the World Cup on home soil. Sergino Dest is also poised to play his first match for the USMNT since recovering an ACL injury he sustained last year, while Josh Sargent is back in the mix after being left off the Gold Cup squad in a "football decision." Weston McKennie, meanwhile, headlines the list of mainstays who did not make the cut, something Pochettino described as being part of the spirit of player pool expansion. The USMNT will convene in New Jersey next week ahead of a friendly against South Korea on Sept. 6 at Sports Illustrated Stadium, followed by a friendly against Japan three days later at Columbus' Lower.com Field. The final round of UEFA Champions League qualification will wrap up on Wednesday, with eight teams competing for the last four spots in the competition in time for Thursday's league phase draw in Monaco. Here's a look at the first leg scores for the last incomplete ties on the qualification schedule. These eight teams will take to the pitch after a dramatic day in Europe on Tuesday, when three first-time Champions League participants -- Norway's Bodo/Glimt, Cyprus' Pafos FC and Kazakhstan's Kairat-- all advanced, in some cases beating competition regulars to book their spots. Glimt's 5-0 first leg victory over Sturm Graz paved the way for a straightforward 6-2 aggregate win on Tuesday, while Pafos defeated Crvena zvezda 3-2 on aggregate thanks to an 89th minute goal from Jaja. Kairat, though, completed the lengthiest and most arduous path to the Champions League by taking Celtic to penalties after 210 minutes of goalless play over two legs, with goalkeeper Temirlan Anarbekov making three saves in the shootout. Kairat entered in the first round of qualification back at the start of July and are now the second-ever Kazakh team to make the Champions League after Astana did so in the 2015-16 season. The headlining act of Wednesday's action will take place in Lisbon, where Benfica host Fenerbahce after a scoreless draw in Istanbul last week. Fenerbahce manager Jose Mourinho makes his return to Benfica, where he held his first managerial role in a brief spell almost exactly 25 years ago, but enters the match as the underdogs -- the Portuguese team are a Champions League regular while his side have not played in the competition in almost 20 years. It means Mourinho's pre-match reflections come with a hint of practicality, even if he is still willing and able to talk a big game. üá∫üá∏ USMNT-ers on the move: After a busy summer for a handful of USMNT players, here's who has the most to gain as the competition for World Cup roster spots gets underway. üî• Can you feel the heat? Pressure is already on Manchester United manager Ruben Amorim, so much that an EFL League Cup match against Grimsby Town is crucial for them to win. üá¶üá∑ A rising star: Argentina's next big talent may just be Nico Paz. But why in the world would Italian club Como reject $70 million for a player, but maybe sell him for $10 million? üî¥ Meet Rio Ngumoha: Liverpool have a new young star, and he's already making a ton of noise. ‚ú® NWSL Team of the Week: USWNT's Alyssa Thompson leads this week's best XI. üî¥ Liverpool's fun imbalance: Liverpool's attack-minded rebuild might make them a defensive liability, but their flair for the dramatic should be encouraged for the sake of entertainment. Announcer Ian Darke to make Fox return for 2026 World Cup: Source
Source: The New York Times    Published: 2025-08-27 15:27:13

World Cup One of the most iconic voices in global soccer is returning to Fox for the 2026 World Cup in North America. Veteran World Cup broadcaster Ian Darke will join Fox Sports as a play-by-play broadcaster during its coverage of the 2026 World Cup, an industry source briefed on Fox's plans told The Athletic. Advertisement Darke currently calls La Liga games for ESPN in the United States. He also calls Premier League games on a freelance basis in the United Kingdom. The assignment would be Darke's ninth World Cup as an announcer. He worked for ABC and ESPN during the men's World Cups in 1994, 2010 and 2014, as well as the Women's World Cup in 2011. He later called the 2018 World Cup in Russia for the world feed, and ESPN loaned him to Fox for the 2022 tournament. Darke's first World Cup assignment was in 1982 for BBC Radio. He also announced one for Australian television (SBS) in 1998. ‚ÄúI love the World Cup, and I think any soccer commentator would be lying to you if they said they didn't want to do the World Cup regardless of the controversial venue. By hook or by crook, I have managed to get assigned,‚Äù Darke told The Athletic in 2022 upon getting the World Cup assignment from Fox. Fox declined to comment. Darke was famously on the call in 2010 when Landon Donovan's 91st-minute goal sent the United States past Algeria and into the knockout stage. He and Donovan worked together at Fox for the 2022 World Cup as well as for coverage of the 2024 European Championship. The World Cup draw is currently scheduled to take place on Dec. 5 at The Kennedy Center, the performing arts and events space in D.C. The 2026 World Cup, which will be played across the U.S., Canada and Mexico, begins on June 11. (Photo: Kim Klement / Imagn Images) Spot the pattern. Connect the terms Find the hidden link between sports terms Play today's puzzle Richard Deitsch is a media reporter for The Athletic. He previously worked for 20 years for Sports Illustrated, where he covered seven Olympic Games, multiple NCAA championships and U.S. Open tennis. Richard also hosts a weekly sports media podcast. Follow Richard on Twitter @richarddeitsch

Mauricio Pochettino sends clear message to Christian Pulisic after new USMNT call up and Gold Cup snub
Source: World Soccer Talk    Published: 2025-08-27 15:00:21

by Francisco Quatrin August 27, 2025 With the 2026 FIFA World Cup approaching quickly, head coach Mauricio Pochettino is fine-tuning his vision for the U.S. Men's National Team (USMNT). His latest 22-man roster for friendlies against South Korea and Japan reflects that long-term planning: a mix of established stars, returning leaders as Christian Pulisic, and emerging prospects fighting for a chance to prove themselves. Pochettino framed the camp as one of the last windows to evaluate new faces before shifting fully toward competitive preparations. The goal, he emphasized, is not just about winning these friendlies, but about building depth and balance for the challenges that lie ahead in 2026. The headline name is Christian Pulisic, who returns to the squad after sitting out the Gold Cup earlier this summer for personal reasons. The AC Milan midfielder remains one of the USMNT's most influential figures, and his inclusion reassures fans eager to see the American star leading the team again. Pochettino downplayed any lingering questions about Pulisic's absence. The Argentine coach highlighted his strong preseason in Italy and his sharp early-season form, noting that the plan now is to reintegrate him smoothly: ‚ÄúHe's rested, fresh, and ready to contribute.‚Äù Perhaps the biggest surprise was the absence of Weston McKennie. A regular fixture in the USMNT midfield, the Juventus player was left out as Pochettino stressed the need to let him regain rhythm at his club after a shortened preseason due to the Club World Cup. see also Thomas Muller accidentally reveals Pochettino's surprise USMNT call-up from Vancouver Whitecaps The same approach applied to Johnny Cardoso, who was also omitted. For Pochettino, the message is clear: no player's spot is guaranteed. He wants his established veterans fully fit and in form, while also creating room for less familiar names to stake their claim. In one of his most emphatic points, Pochettino made it clear he does not believe in automatic starters or untouchable names: ‚ÄúI don't have a number one. Every player has the same opportunity to fight for a place.‚Äù With a pool of nearly 60 players under evaluation, the challenge will be narrowing that list down to 26 for the World Cup. This open competition has energized the squad. Veterans like Pulisic and newcomers alike know that every camp matters, and that the fight for roster spots will be intense until the very end. Another encouraging note is the inclusion of Giovanni Reyna, now 22 and looking to reignite his career at Borussia M√∂nchengladbach. Long viewed as one of the brightest young talents in American soccer, Reyna's ability to return to consistent minutes in Germany could be pivotal for both his career and the national team. Rio Ferdinand says the person responsible for letting David de Gea leave Manchester United should have been "made redundant" in a plea to re-sign him.

Haitian government grants over $700K to support national soccer team
Source: The Haitian Times    Published: 2025-08-27 13:26:05

Keep tabs on the latest news out of Haiti and the diaspora delivered straight to your inbox. | The Haitian Times Bridging the gap Haiti's government has granted 100 million gourdes (about $770,000) to back its national soccer teams. The funds will support the U-17 men's squad for the 2025 FIFA World Cup in Qatar, as well as the senior men's and women's teams as they prepare for crucial World Cup and Olympic qualifiers. PORT-AU-PRINCE ‚Äî The Haitian government presented a check of 100 million gourdes, equivalent to approximately $770,000, during an official ceremony in Port-au-Prince on Monday, Aug. 25, to Haiti's soccer federation to support the national teams' preparations, especially the under-17 men's team that will represent the country at the 2025 FIFA World Cup this November in Qatar. The event brought together Prime Minister Alix Didier Fils-Aim√©, Youth and Sports Minister Niola Lynn Sarah Octavius, Finance Minister Alfred Fils M√©tellus and Gally Amazan, a member of the Haitian Football Federation's (FHF) committee. Sign up for our free newsletters. ‚ÄúYou will carry to Qatar the dream of a people who believe in you,‚Äù Fils-Aim√© told the young players. ‚ÄúThe flag you will bear is not just a symbol; it is the soul of Haiti.‚Äù The U-17 Grenadiers, led by coach Eddy C√©sar, qualified in February with three wins out of three games in the final qualifiers' round. They will face Venezuela, England and Egypt in Group E of the 2025 FIFA World Cup, scheduled for Nov. 3‚Äì27. This will be Haiti's third appearance at the global tournament in this category, after competing in 2007 and 2019, when they were eliminated in the group stage each time. The FHF said in a statement on Facebook that the funds will be used not only for U-17 training camps but also to support the senior men's team engaged in the final phase of the 2026 World Cup qualifiers starting Sept. 5, and the senior women's team as they enter the preliminary stage of the Concacaf W Championship in November ‚Äî a qualifier for the 2027 World Cup in Brazil, the 2028 Olympics in Los Angeles, CA and the 2029 Gold Cup. ‚ÄúThis support represents a major lever to aid the preparation of our national teams and meet the logistical demands of high-level competitions,‚Äù the FHF said in a statement. The federation added that the investment could encourage more private sector partnerships for Haiti's soccer program. ‚ÄúThe flag you will bear is not just a symbol; it is the soul of Haiti. Every step you take on the field will be a step for the dignity, unity, and greatness of our Nation.‚Äù Octavius praised the U-17 squad's discipline and urged them to ‚Äúredouble their efforts to raise the Haitian flag on the world stage proudly.‚Äù But she also acknowledged the difficulties: Haiti's largest training center has been closed since gangs took over Croix-des-Bouquets, and insecurity has hampered talent scouting and facility upgrades. The grant follows a $150,000 contribution on Aug. 1 by the betting company Paryaj Lakay, which partnered with the FHF to support the U-17s. ‚ÄúThey are our future,‚Äù the company said at the time. ‚ÄúThere's no bigger pride than waving our flag for the world to see.‚Äù Officials stressed that despite the country's turmoil, soccer remains a symbol of unity and resilience. ‚ÄúEvery step you take on the field will be a step for the dignity, unity, and greatness of our Nation,‚Äù Prime Minister Fils-Aim√© said. As an independent publication, we rely on contributions from readers like you to fund our journalism. Thanks for your contribution! I am Juhakenson Blaise, a journalist based in the city of Port-au-Prince, Haiti. I cover the news that develops in this city and deals with other subjects related to the experience of Haitians for the Haitian Times newspaper. I am also a lover of poetry. Meet Ghana's German-born debutant gearing up for World Cup qualifiers
Source: GhanaWeb    Published: 2025-08-27 13:09:40

Sign in to continue Sign in to continue Sign up to get started Derrick Arthur Kohn has earned a debut call up to the Black Stars Ghana has drafted German-born defender Derrick Arthur Kohn into the Black Stars squad for next month's 2026 FIFA World Cup qualifiers. The 26-year-old versatile left-back, who previously represented Germany at the youth level, has now pledged his international future to Ghana. He could make his senior debut in the 2026 World Cup qualifiers, when Otto Addo's side face Chad and Mali in Group I on September 4, 2025, and September 6, 2025, respectively. Born in Hamburg to Ghanaian parents, Kohn began his football journey with Hamburg's U-19 side during the 2016/17 season. Watch highglights of Black Stars new boy Derrick Kohn His talent quickly caught the eye of scouts, and he was snapped up by Bayern Munich's reserve side, where he spent three seasons developing his craft in Germany's lower divisions. In search of regular top-flight football, Kohn moved to the Netherlands in 2019, signing for Willem II, where he played for two seasons in the Eredivisie. His performances earned him a move back to Germany in 2022, joining Hannover 96, where he became one of the club's most consistent performers. His steady rise did not go unnoticed. In 2024, Turkish giants Galatasaray paid ‚Ç¨3.4 million to sign him but immediately sent him on loan to Werder Bremen for the 2024/25 Bundesliga season. It proved to be a breakthrough campaign for Kohn as he made 27 league appearances, scoring twice and providing two assists, a strong return for a defender. Following that success, Kohn secured a permanent transfer to Union Berlin in the summer of 2025. He made his debut for the club in their Bundesliga opener against Stuttgart on Saturday, August 23, 2025, coming off the bench in the 67th minute. Although he featured for Germany's youth national teams earlier in his career, Kohn remained eligible for Ghana through his parents and has now embraced the opportunity to represent the Black Stars at the senior level. His versatility, pace, and attacking threat from the left flank are seen as key assets for Otto Addo's side. For Kohn, this maiden call-up represents the start of a new chapter, one that gives him the chance to contribute to Ghana's push for a fifth World Cup appearance. Kohn joins the Black Stars at the peak of his career, bringing with him the experience of Germany, the Netherlands, and Turkey, and the hunger to make his mark on the international stage. FKA/EB Meanwhile, watch the new episode of Sports Check with Ali Jarrah below: Sports Copyright ¬© 1994 - 2025 GhanaWeb. All rights reserved.

Wolves head coach Vitor Pereira has admitted that "every player has a price" as Newcastle chase a deal for Jorgen Strand Larsen. The Magpies have submitted a new bid for the Norwegian striker, who scored twice to help Wolves beat West Ham 3-2 in the second round of the Carabao Cup on Tuesday night.

Women's soccer fans support the brands that support their favorite players and teams
Source: The New York Times    Published: 2025-08-27 10:00:43

Log in Subscribe Now Current Edition: International Search Top News Podcasts Connections: Sports Edition NFL Home Teams Scores & Schedule Standings NFL Draft Scoop City Newsletter Podcasts Fantasy NFL Odds NFL Picks AFC Projections NFC Projections Roster Cuts Tracker MLB Home Teams Scores & Schedule Standings Podcasts The Windup Newsletter Fantasy MLB Prospects MLB Odds MLB Picks Latest Power Rankings Top 60 Prospects NCAAF Home Teams Scores & Schedule Standings Podcasts Until Saturday Newsletter Recruiting Odds Picks CFP Predictor Quizzes The Athletic 136 Rankings Freaks List 2025 QB Tiers Coaching Tiers Rivalry Rankings NBA Home Teams Scores & Schedule Standings The Bounce Newsletter NBA Draft Podcasts Fantasy NBA Odds NBA Picks Offseason Grades 2025-26 Schedule Highlights NHL Home Teams Scores & Schedule Standings Podcasts Fantasy NHL Odds NHL Picks Free-Agent Big Board Red Light Newsletter WNBA Home Teams Scores & Schedule Standings Podcasts Fantasy Football Home Betting NFL Home Podcasts Draft Kit Customizable Rankings Fantasy Draft Rankings Dynasty and Rookie-only Rankings Printable Cheat Sheet Projections Discord NCAAM Home Teams Scores & Schedule Bracket Standings Podcasts Best Coaches Since 2000 NCAAW Home Scores & Schedule Bracket Standings Podcasts Way-too-early Top 25 Premier League Home Teams Scores & Schedule Standings Fantasy The Athletic FC Newsletter Podcasts Mainoo's Man Utd Future Gyokeres' Trademark Goal Life as a Football Prodigy Tennis Home U.S. Open 2025 Updates Golf Home Peak College Sports Global Sports Soccer Women's Soccer Home Women's Euros Bracket NWSL Schedule Full Time Newsletter Podcasts Women's Euros Women's World Cup NWSL USWNT College Sports MLS Home Teams Scores & Schedule Standings Podcasts NWSL Home Scores & Schedule Standings Full Time newsletter Podcasts Formula 1 Home Prime Tire newsletter Schedule Standings McLaren Ferrari Red Bull Mercedes Aston Martin Alpine Haas Racing Bulls Williams Sauber Olympics Home Sports Business Home MoneyCall Newsletter Opinion Home Betting Home Odds Fantasy Baseball NFL Picks UK Betting Fantasy Baseball Home MLB Home Podcasts Betting Starting Pitcher Rankings Terminology Memorabilia and Collectibles Culture Home Motorsports Home Podcasts NASCAR Women's Hockey Home MMA Home Boxing Home Moses Itauma vs. Dillian Whyte The Pulse Newsletter Cities U.S. Open Ryder Cup Transfer Updates Today's News Connections: Sports Edition Newsletters Women's Soccer For years, brands' default narrative for women's soccer marketing was great stories, inspiring athletes, but commercially unproven. Sponsors stayed conservative, sticking with the NFL, NBA, MLB and men's soccer, where the math was predictable. Women's soccer was often seen as a nice-to-have, not a must-have. Advertisement Now, the data says otherwise. Earlier this summer, Parity, a sports marketing and sponsorship platform focused on professional women athletes across 85 sports, ran a survey on women's sports fandom in the United States. It sampled 2,400 sports fans across multiple disciplines, finding that 63 percent of respondents said they watch women's soccer. One in four said they watch only women's soccer, with 49 percent saying they watch NWSL and 32 percent saying they follow Gainbridge Super League, the other Division I professional league in the U.S. That's a staggering statistic for both leagues; the NWSL is barely a decade old, and the Super League is only just beginning its second season. But fans are not just watching, they're investing. The survey found that more than one in four fans of women's soccer have made a purchase because of a brand's sponsorship, making them 58 percent more likely to do so compared to fans of other women's sports. Translation: Women's soccer fans see sponsorships less as sales pitches and more as solidarity. For brands, that is the holy grail. ‚ÄúWe looked at fans in basketball, soccer, volleyball, softball, etc, and we couldn't believe what we saw for soccer,‚Äù Leela Srinivasan, the CEO of Parity, told The Athletic. Since she took the reins in May 2023, Parity has amassed a network of over 800 women athletes and paid out over $2 million in sponsorships. ‚ÄúIt just stood out head and shoulders above other fandoms or other sports,‚Äù Srinivasan said. The culture of soccer is part of the equation. ‚ÄúThe passion runs deep in soccer, wherever it's happening in the world,‚Äù explained Srinivasan, who grew up as a season ticket holder for Dundee in the Scottish Premiership. ‚ÄúI think it runs deeper, arguably, in women's soccer here in the U.S. than in men's soccer, in part, because the U.S. national team has been such a force for so many years.‚Äù Advertisement That passion has been translated into a commercial engine for a while. The U.S. women's team attracted a roster of blue-chip sponsors under the U.S. Soccer umbrella: Volkswagen, Allstate, Jim Beam, AT&T, Marriott Bonvoy, Anheuser-Busch, New York Life, Bank of America and The Home Depot are listed as official partners. ‚ÄúIn the U.S., it almost feels like soccer is a women's sport ‚Äî we don't face the same uphill battle that women's basketball players or soccer players in Europe or South America do,‚Äù Angel City defender Ali Riley said. ‚ÄúYes, MLS is growing and there's huge anticipation for the men's World Cup, but the success of our women's national team has made women's soccer here impossible to ignore. ‚ÄúThose players, from the '99ers onward, fought for respect and built the foundation we stand on. They didn't get today's engagement, loyalty or brand support, but they paved the way ‚Äî many now owning clubs, launching businesses and creating opportunities for the next generation.‚Äù Parity also found that women's soccer fans tend to pay attention to athlete endorsements and are 34 percent more likely than other women's sports fans to trust athletes. Athlete product collabs are the primary way they want to see brands activate, with nearly half saying they would be likely to engage with brands that do so. ‚ÄúPeople want to see brands investing more in women's sports, and the fans are most excited about when brands partner directly with athletes, whether it's collaborating with products or just building that athlete relationship,‚Äù Srinivasan said. ‚ÄúBecause that unlocks all kinds of storytelling for the brands and helps the fans get closer to the athlete that they still admire.‚Äù Today's players are more than athletes; they're entrepreneurs, activists and culturally relevant voices who no longer wait for a brand to give them a voice or script their image. They are building narratives on social media, and that authenticity is priceless for brands. Advertisement With 11 active brand deals, Riley leads all NWSL players in endorsements, according to Sponsor United's report. That is notable not just because she's surpassed her peers, but because she has done it as a non-U.S. women's national team player, a big contrast to the Alex Morgan era, when Morgan's 23-deal peak in 2021 defined endorsement dominance. Chasing Riley are Mallory Swanson (10), Sophia Smith (9) and Alyssa Thompson (8), a new generation of stars just steps behind. ‚ÄúWith the partnerships I've been fortunate to have and the team supporting me, both clubs and players are getting unprecedented exposure,‚Äù Riley said. She never felt she could compete with U.S. national team stars like Morgan, but she is doing it. ‚ÄúBack then, it felt like there was just one sponsorship to go around ‚Äî Nike, maybe one or two others ‚Äî and only a handful of athletes got that support. ‚ÄúThat's finally changing. The data on fan engagement and loyalty is undeniable, and brands are realizing it's smart business to back us. The pie itself has grown, and now the share we're competing for is much bigger. On top of that, I've got someone advocating for me, pitching my value directly to brands ‚Äî and that makes all the difference.‚Äù In the 48 hours after the Parity report dropped, the biggest reaction came not from sponsors, but from soccer clubs, according to Srinivasan. They finally had hard data to show brands what they had known all along: Women's soccer delivers. On the league side, the numbers are even more impressive. Sponsors United, a global sports and entertainment intelligence platform that provides data and insights for marketing partnerships, shared its first NWSL report this year. It shows teams pulled in $75 million in sponsorship revenue last year, with 441 deals across 401 brands in 167 different categories. That is a 16 percent jump in category breadth since 2022. The average team is banking about $5.4 million in sponsorship revenue, with roughly $170,000 per deal. Advertisement On a per-game basis, NWSL teams are generating more sponsorship revenue than WNBA teams, despite playing fewer games. Still, the money is clustered at the top, with the top three clubs accounting for 46 percent of the league's sponsorship haul. Angel City FC, which launched in 2022, has the highest sponsorship revenue, followed by Kansas City Current and San Diego Wave. Gainbridge, the USL Super League's naming sponsor, sees the potential growth as a big upside. ‚ÄúWhat I've seen traditionally through women's sports is a lot of brands take a wait-and-see attitude. Sometimes, if you take that wait-and-see attitude, the time never comes. If nobody gets involved, then it doesn't succeed,‚Äù Mike Nichols, chief of sponsorship strategy and activation at Group 1001 (parent company to Gainbridge), said. A post shared by Gainbridge Sports (@gainbridgesport) Gainbridge became the title sponsor of the USL Super League this season and sponsors several prominent women's sports entities, including the Billie Jean King Cup by Gainbridge and the ANNIKA driven by Gainbridge LPGA event. The company allocates over 40 percent of its sponsorship dollars to women's sports and features a roster of brand ambassadors such as Caitlin Clark, Billie Jean King and former USWNT goalkeeper Briana Scurry. ‚ÄúWe're in the financial services space, which is very crowded in the sports ecosystem,‚Äù Nichols said. ‚ÄúSo to be in a situation where there was a lot of white space, and as a financial services brand, we could come in and chart our own direction, as opposed to trying to fit in with what's available, is an incredible opportunity that really doesn't, frankly, ever present itself, especially if you sort of take a wait-and-see attitude. ‚ÄúThe USL has an academy that has over 10,000 kids, boys and girls in it, and those parents are people that we want to ultimately have as our customers. With those sorts of opportunities, we're just scratching the surface with the league just kicking off.‚Äù While North America is known for its big four men's leagues, both Parity and SU's reports underline the steady growth of soccer fandom, and it is not just the game that's becoming more popular. Parity's data shows advertising in soccer pays like no other sport, something brands should consider in the lead-up to the upcoming FIFA World Cups and the NWSL and Super League's combined year-round domestic calendar. Advertisement Fans know when game day is. They plan around it. They make it a ritual. Rituals build loyalty, and loyalty builds commerce. ‚ÄúSoccer fans in this country have always believed in us, even when games weren't televised and merchandise didn't exist,‚Äù Riley said. ‚ÄúNow, with brands finally doing the smart thing and backing us, fans are all in. Their appetite has been building for decades, and the response shows just how strong that loyalty really is.‚Äù There is also another shift worth noting: visibility. The NWSL's $240 million media rights deal over four years with CBS, ESPN, Amazon's Prime Video and Scripps Sports represents a forty-fold jump from the NWSL's previous, $1.5 million annual tie-up with CBS and changed the calculus overnight. For the first time, the deal put 11 games of the season on prime-time cable television, making the sport more attractive to sponsors. In sponsorship math, reach still matters. A player who appears on national TV multiple times a season instantly becomes a safer bet for brand dollars. ‚ÄúIt certainly doesn't hurt. If you talk to a head of sponsorship at the brand today and ask them how they measure success, a lot of brands are still going, if not solely, then at least largely, based on number of eyeballs,‚Äù Srinivasan explained. While Parity and Sponsor United's reports are based on the U.S., soccer is the world's game. This summer's UEFA European Women's Championship broke viewership records among U.S. audiences, and clubs like Barcelona Femen√≠ and Arsenal FC Women are drawing record crowds into their stadiums. Ownership groups with multi-club portfolios, like Michele Kang's Kynisca, are increasingly investing in the women's side, knowing that cross-pollination between markets (U.S., Europe, Mexico) is inevitable. Europe's women's soccer commercial infrastructure might be behind the U.S., but the momentum is there. As more leagues secure broadcast deals and sponsors step in, the growth curve looks remarkably familiar to what we have seen stateside. In other words, global brands should already be plotting their women's soccer strategy. Advertisement ‚ÄúAs one of our other brand ambassadors, Billie Jean King, likes to say, ‚ÄòThis isn't charity,'‚Äù Nichols said. ‚ÄúWhen she founded the Women's Sports Foundation 50 years ago with the idea that this day would come where women's sports would be looked at as a viable business opportunity, not just a charitable thing to do, as opposed to, hey, it's good for business. And that moment finally came.‚Äù (Top photo: Spire Motorsports / Gainbridge) Spot the pattern. Connect the terms Find the hidden link between sports terms Play today's puzzle Asli Pelit is a journalist at The Athletic covering the NWSL, the U.S. women's national team and the business of women's soccer. She has reported on the global game since 2013, for TRT Sport, USA Today Sports, VICE, Forbes, and most recently was a staff writer at Sportico. Pelit holds a B.A. in Journalism from New York University, an MBA from Columbia Business School and was a 2020-2021 Knight-Bagehot Fellow. Follow Asli on Twitter @asli_pelit

Five reasons why Joan Garcia will prove to be an ideal signing for Barcelona Barcelona's Unsung Heroes: Under-the-radar stars who made a difference this season Ranking all 15 La Masia talents that made their Barcelona debut under Xavi Barcelona talented La Masia graduate's market value rises to ‚Ç¨75 million Barcelona delighted with the progress of 15-year-old La Masia talent ‚Äì report ‚ÄòLa Masia is the essence of Bar√ßa' ‚Äì Barcelona academy gem reacts after La Liga debut Deco wants to build Barcelona's future with La Masia Published on By Chelsea are planning a major move for Barcelona midfielder Fermin Lopez this summer. In fact, according to Miguel Rico in COPE, the London club is ready to offer Fermin a staggering ‚Ç¨15 million net salary, which is more than double his current ‚Ç¨6 million at Bar√ßa. This shows how serious Chelsea are about landing the talented midfielder and convincing him to leave the Catalan club. Fermin's name started making headlines after reports suggested Chelsea are preparing a ‚Ç¨50 million bid. Their manager, Enzo Maresca, has already reached out to the player twice, trying to persuade him to join the Premier League side. While Fermin has always expressed his love for Barcelona, recent events appear to have made him rethink his future. Notably, he did not play a single minute in the match against Levante last Saturday, leaving him frustrated and open to new possibilities. Barcelona are fully aware of Chelsea's interest and the discussions Maresca has had with Fermin. The club has tried to get in touch with the midfielder throughout the day, but so far, he has not responded. His silence has been interpreted as a sign that he is seriously considering Chelsea's offer. If he decides to make the move, his salary would jump from ‚Ç¨6 million to ‚Ç¨15 million, a significant financial incentive. While Fermin's loyalty to Barcelona remains clear, players in his position often face tough decisions when top European clubs come knocking with high offers. Chelsea's willingness to pay such a high salary underlines their financial muscle, and Fermin's next move could be a defining moment for both clubs. As of now, everything points to a potential summer transfer, but nothing has been finalised. Barcelona will continue to monitor the situation closely, hoping to retain one of their brightest talents, while Chelsea appear determined to secure him at almost three times his current earnings. Former Indiana men's soccer goalkeeper Roman Celentano named to USMNT
Source: Indiana Daily Student    Published: 2025-08-27 00:07:00

Former Indiana men's soccer player and current FC Cincinnati goalkeeper Roman Celentano will join the U.S. men's national soccer team for the upcoming FIFA International Window. Celentano is one of three goalkeepers to make the 23-man roster. FC Cincinnati drafted Celentano No. 2 overall in the 2022 Major League Soccer SuperDraft following a prolific three-year career with the Hoosiers. The Naperville, Illinois, native totaled 52 appearances with Indiana, securing 28 shutouts and a .62 goals-against average. Celentano earned two All-America selections, and he is still the only player to win two Big Ten Goalkeeper of the Year awards. Since joining FC Cincinnati, Celentano has started in all 118 of his appearances. He featured in every match but one in the 2023 MLS season, a year in which Cincinnati won the Supporters' Shield for having the most points in the regular season. Celentano has started in every MLS match for Cincinnati in the 2025 season, racking up nine clean sheets and a 1.25 goals per game average. He broke the club record for total minutes against Charlotte FC on Aug. 10, surpassing midfielder Luciano Acosta with 12,382 minutes across all competitions. The September international window will mark Celentano's second stint with the USMNT, as he first was called up in January 2024. However, he has yet to make a senior appearance for the national team. Follow reporters Elakai Anela (elakai_anela) and Mateo Fuentes-Rohwer (@mateo_frohwer) throughout the Indiana men's soccer season.

TENNIS

Navarro makes quick work of McNally to extend second-round streak
Source: WTA Tennis    Published: 2025-08-27 17:15:00

One year after her breakthrough semifinal run in New York, Emma Navarro needed only 76 minutes to dismiss fellow American Caty McNally and extend her streak of second-round wins at majors to seven. NEW YORK -- One year after her best Grand Slam result, Emma Navarro is into the third round with a clinically clean 6-2, 6-1 victory Wednesday over fellow American Caty McNally. The No. 10 seed, who reached last year's US Open semifinals before losing to eventual champion Aryna Sabalenka, has now won seven consecutive second-round matches at Grand Slams -- this one in just 76 minutes. ‚ÄúIt was a little bit quicker than I tend to play my matches, but it wasn't easy,‚Äù Navarro said in her on-court interview. There's been some ups and downs this year, but there's something special in the air here.‚Äù This year's path to the final four looks more difficult. Next up for Navarro: The winner of the later match between two-time Grand Slam singles champion Barbora Krejcikova and Moyuka Uchijima. No. 5 seed Mirra Andreeva could await in the fourth round. Navarro, 24, is now 2-0 against McNally, who was playing on a wild card granted by the USTA. McNally, 23, was trying to equal her best Grand Slam performance; she reached the third round here five years ago. She's now gone 0-8 against Top 20 players in the PIF WTA Rankings. The match, played on a beautiful breezy day on the well-attended Grandstand Court, got off to a scratchy start, with three consecutive service breaks. But when a McNally forehand strayed long, at the 22-minute mark, it was 3-1, Navarro. There was another break in the seventh game and Navarro nailed down the first set when she converted her third set point. Confidence building üìàEmma Navarro is into the third round in New York.#USOpen pic.twitter.com/PMoYzWibJL Navarro got off to a quick 3-0 start in the second, but McNally broke through in the fourth game. Navarro shrugged it off, winning the last three games of the match, finishing with a forehand winner into the open court. Remarkably, Navarro won seven of her eight break-point opportunities. She finished with 10 winners, against nine unforced errors. McNally finished with nine and 33, respectively. Azarenka moves on She's 36 now and ranked outside the Top 100, but Victoria Azarenka -- a two-time Grand Slam champion -- still has some championship chops. Her 6-3, 6-3 victory over No. 45-ranked Anastasia Pavlyuchenkova created several noteworthy milestones. Azarenka became: ‚ÄúShe started really strong,‚Äù Azarenka said of Pavlyuchenkova's early 3-0 lead. ‚ÄúI felt like had to find a little bit my feet, make a few more first balls and start dictating.‚Äù Azarenka ultimately won 12 of the last 15 games. The win over Pavlyuchenkova in Stadium 17 was her eighth in 10 meetings, the most she's had against any other player. Among active players, only Venus Williams (94) has appeared in more Grand Slam main draws than Azarenka (69). Azarenka broke Pavlyuchenkova five times and finished with four more winners than unforced errors, 15-11. One year after her breakthrough semifinal run in New York, Emma Navarro needed only 76 minutes to dismiss fellow American Caty McNally and extend her streak of second-round wins at majors to seven.

Venus accepts wild card into US Open doubles, will play with Fernandez
Source: WTA Tennis    Published: 2025-08-27 16:28:20

Venus Williams has accepted a wild card into the doubles draw at the US Open, where she'll play with former singles finalist Leylah Fernandez. Venus has won the US Open doubles title twice -- first in 1999, and then in 2009, both time with her sister. NEW YORK -- She just can't quit the US Open. After losing in the revamped mixed doubles tournament with Reilly Opelka, and then dropping her first-round match against 11th-seeded Karolina Muchova -- a three-setter that saw her even the match after dropping the first -- Venus Williams will stick around in Queens for a bit longer to play doubles. The 45-year-old icon has accepted a wild card into the doubles draw alongside former US Open finalist Leylah Fernandez. (Fernandez is still in the singles draw after defeating Rebecca Marino in the first round. She'll play Elsa Jacquemot in the second round on Wednesday.) A post shared by US Open (@usopen) Williams, a two-time US Open singles champion, has also won two doubles titles in Flushing Meadows -- in 1999, alongside her sister, and then again ten years later (again with Serena). The seven-time Slam singles champ was certainly feeling the love from the New York crowd in Arthur Ashe Stadium on Monday night, and after the match she said it was perhaps the most supportive crowd she's ever played in front of. (And that's saying something, considering she's been on the Hologic WTA Tour since 1994 and has won 23 total majors.) "I don't think I've ever had a crowd that much on my side," she said. "When I lost those first two games, they were just still right there with me every point. Didn't matter if I was losing and it was starting to roll fast, they were just right there with me. It felt great. "I knew going into this match that people in this stadium, people in the United States, people around the world were really rooting for me, and that felt great." Fernandez is a fitting partner for Williams. In Cincinnati, when the reigning Washington D.C. champion was scheduled to potentially play Venus in the third round -- that didn't end up happening, as both players lost before that -- Fernandez talked about her kinship with Williams. "Venus, she's a legend," Fernandez said earlier this summer. "She's an icon. Growing up, when I first started playing tennis, people asked me, 'Who did you watch when you were growing up?' I always said Justine Henin and the Williams sisters. A post shared by TOGETHXR (@togethxr) "I see a lot of similarities between their family and my family. They kind of built the path for us, and if I do have the opportunity to play against her, I'm just gonna be super happy, a little kid living her dream and playing one of her idols." She won't play against her, but will instead play with her -- which is probably even more thrilling. The World No. 30 also recalled meeting Venus back in 2020, when she first turned pro and didn't know many players. It was in August of that year, at the Top Seed Open outside of Lexington, Kentucky, and Fernandez remembers that Venus was one of the first players who wanted to practice with her, something she always appreciated and will never forget. "I thought I was going to be very intimidated, but she was super nice and welcoming," Fernandez said. "She encouraged me, so it was pretty cool." Williams and Fernandez will play sixth-seeded Lyudmyla Kichenok and Ellen Perez in the first round. Venus Williams has accepted a wild card into the doubles draw at the US Open, where she'll play with former singles finalist Leylah Fernandez. Venus has won the US Open doubles title twice -- first in 1999, and then in 2009, both time with her sister.

"It must have fire": Aryna Sabalenka helps create limited-edition Wilson Blade racquet
Source: Tennis.com    Published: 2025-08-27 05:15:00

The world No. 1 is swinging the Fighter Edition, boasting a colorful and fierce cosmetic‚Äîand toting it in an equally unique bag.ByJon LeveyPublished Aug 27, 2025 copy_link Published Aug 27, 2025 ¬© Matt Fitzgerald It must have fire. That was Aryna Sabalenka's request to Wilson. Back in the spring, the world No. 1 approached her racquet sponsor with the idea of creating her own custom Blade. The cosmetics should be bold and aggressive to reflect her on-court passion and power. And some flames wouldn't hurt.Wilson obliged with a fiery mix of color on the frame that channels Sabalenka's inner warrior. There's even her signature tiger tattoo emblazoned on the throat. The top seed will play with her limited-edition Blade 98 (16x19) v9 Fighter Edition throughout her run at the US Open. Wilson obliged with a fiery mix of color on the frame that channels Sabalenka's inner warrior. There's even her signature tiger tattoo emblazoned on the throat. The top seed will play with her limited-edition Blade 98 (16x19) v9 Fighter Edition throughout her run at the US Open. Supply of the Blade 98 Fighter Edition ($269) is truly limited. Approximately 100 models were available at the Wilson store on the US Open grounds. A post shared by Aryna Sabalenka (@arynasabalenka) Sabalenka had recently switched to Evolve‚ÄîNaomi Osaka' management company‚Äîand was looking for ways to expand on her endorsement deals when she proposed the racquet idea to Wilson. Over the past few years, the brand has created opportunities, whether racquets or apparel, to personalize equipment for their athletes. This also gives Blade users another unique option to add to their collection.Although Sabalenka technically endorses the Blade 98 (18x20), the Fighter Edition is only offered with the 16x19 string pattern. It's the more widely used model among players, providing a bit more power and spin. It would be an easier transition for potential adopters inspired by the Sabalenka colorway. Although Sabalenka technically endorses the Blade 98 (18x20), the Fighter Edition is only offered with the 16x19 string pattern. It's the more widely used model among players, providing a bit more power and spin. It would be an easier transition for potential adopters inspired by the Sabalenka colorway. Sabalenka walks onto court with her new weapon in tow.¬© Matt Fitzgerald ¬© Matt Fitzgerald The ninth generation of the hugely popular player's frame features the new StableFeel technology. It bolsters the racquet's firmness and resistance to bending and twisting without losing its trademark feel. This gives the racquet even greater control and a more predictable response, giving users more confidence to go for their shots.Supply of the Blade 98 Fighter Edition ($269) is truly limited. Approximately 100 models were available at the Wilson store on the US Open grounds from 8/25 to 8/27. Additionally, there will be about 1000 models available worldwide on wilson.com and at select tennis retailers. Supply of the Blade 98 Fighter Edition ($269) is truly limited. Eliot Spizzirri & squash twin Nick: From childhood tantrums to shining on global stage
Source: ATP Tour    Published: 2025-08-27 04:41:15

Eliot Spizzirri earned the biggest win of his career Sunday when he defeated Stefan Dostanic in the first round of the US Open. It was the 23-year-old's first main draw victory at a major and just the third tour-level win of his career. But the former University of Texas star is not the only member of his family enjoying a special week. His twin brother, Nick, helped the United States' team win the Pan Am Championships in squash. While Eliot has been thriving in New York, Nick was shining in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. ‚ÄúWe were both ranked 124 in the world at the same time, on the same day [in June], so it's pretty close,‚Äù a smiling Eliot said. ‚ÄúI'd say we're both trying to make pushes. We have a healthy relationship of course. He's my best friend and I want the best for him.‚Äù Eliot and Nick played tennis, squash and golf growing up in Connecticut. The brothers would often face one another in a local club championship. ‚ÄúIt would end pretty horribly for one of us, obviously the losing one. [There were] some severe tantrums where our parents had to control us and had to get us all sorted after the loss,‚Äù Eliot recalled. ‚ÄúMy dad I wouldn't say pushed us, but he was adamant about us trying different things so we weren't playing each other all the time. Luckily enough Nick gravitated a little bit more to squash and I gravitated towards tennis, so we weren't playing each other as often, which was a plus.‚Äù In retrospect, Eliot would have loved if Nick played tennis. But they both have found success in their own sport. Eliot spent much of his teens traveling with coach Patrick Hirscht to the USTA Billie Jean King National Tennis Center to train, while his brother improved in squash, ultimately leading him to the University of Pennsylvania. The Spizzirri brothers are not only professional athletes, but family cheerleaders. They are one another's biggest fan and spent time together fishing just days before Nick flew to Brazil. ‚ÄúWe talk every day. He's my best friend in the world. We're always giving each other advice and most of the time we're just joking about stuff that's not tennis or squash,‚Äù Eliot said. ‚ÄúBut when it comes to it, he has a tournament or I have a tournament, we're always bouncing ideas off each other and trying to help each other get as locked in as possible, learn and try to get better.‚Äù Right before Nick flew to the Pan Am Championships, he was ‚Äúin a really bad headspace‚Äù with his squash. Not only was he not enjoying training, but he did not want to go on the court. ‚ÄúI would've rather been at home doing anything else,‚Äù Nick said. ‚ÄúI spoke to my brother about it and he told me that if it were him he'd take a couple days off as I was likely burnt out. It won't affect my level nor my fitness by taking a few days off, it could help me feel more fresh for the tournament as well. ‚ÄúThat's exactly what I did, and when I got to Brazil I achieved some of the biggest wins of my career so far. I was able to defeat the World No. 34 to clinch a U.S. team win over Colombia and ultimately win a Pan Am gold later in the tournament and I believe a lot of the reason I was able to was due to Eliot's advice.‚Äù A post shared by LBSQUASH (@lbsquash) Both twins compete with a lot of fire and emotion and use that to motivate themselves during matches. Off the court, however, Nick explained that they are actually quite different. For example, Eliot is very organised and structured in his daily life. ‚ÄúHis clothes are all folded neatly and his supplements are all placed in a specific order on his desk with his red light glasses on his bureau for when he gets back from training,‚Äù Nick said. ‚ÄúMy room has all my clothes thrown into a pile in the corner and my supplements are all over for me to have to find every morning for when I need to take them. ‚ÄúBasically I am much more laid back off the court. We're both very social. He's more of a nice charismatic character and I am more of a class clown in group scenarios.‚Äù Eliot agrees, saying: ‚ÄúI'm probably more Type A, he's more relaxed. He's kind of a class clown and he's pretty laid back. I don't think I'm as laid back, but I'm trying to learn things from him and maybe vice versa. We're similar in ways and different in others, but he actually has the tennis genes. He's 6'4‚Äù and a little bit bigger than me. Maybe I should have played squash and he should have played tennis.‚Äù It seems to be working out for both brothers at the moment. Spizzirri will try to continue his run at the venue where he spent years training on Wednesday against 32nd seed Luciano Darderi with a potential clash against second seed Carlos Alcaraz looming in the third round. ‚ÄúIt's a dream come true. I remember sneaking through the stadiums here trying to find the loopholes and the shortcuts and training here from such a young age,‚Äù Eliot said. ‚ÄúI was telling someone earlier this week that despite being a wild card, I've probably spent more time on these courts than anyone else in the draw. These are the things you dream of as a kid and the reason why I train so hard to get to this level. It's nice to see it pay off.‚Äù ¬© Copyright 1994 - 2024 ATP Tour, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
