Elizabeth Banks To Star As Karen Read In Limited Series About Infamous Court Case From Prime Video, David E. Kelley, Brownstone & Justin Noble
Source: Deadline    Published: 2025-08-27 16:30:00

By Justin Kroll Film Editor EXCLUSIVE: One of the more polarizing court cases in recent memory is about to get the Hollywood treatment. Sources tell Deadline that Prime Video and Warner Bros Television are in development on a new limited series set around the Karen Read trial, with Elizabeth Banks on board to play the woman at the center of the case. Justin Noble is on board as showrunner and will pen the series and serve as executive producer, with David E. Kelley on board also as executive produce. Noble has an overall deal with Warner Bros Television. Banks also will exec produce through her Brownstone banner along with her producing partner Max Handelman and Krissy Wall. Matt Tinker will exec produce through his David E. Kelley Productions banner along with Matt Tinker. Jen Sargent, Marshall Lewy, Aaron Hart and Jeni Mulein will exec produce through their Wondery banner, as will Rachel Stockman and Dan Abrams through their Law & Crime company. Based on the Law & Crime and Wondery podcast Karen, the series follows the trial that captivated the country and turned Read into a household name. When a Boston police officer is found dead in the snow, all eyes are on his girlfriend, Read. The case fractures a community, with some believing she is guilty of first-degree murder, and others that she's the victim of a sweeping cover-up by state and local law enforcement. This series explores society's obsession with true crime, the allure of conspiracy and the deepening crisis of trust in our institutions. Watch on Deadline The trial became a recurring story on morning talk shows and quickly was turned into multiple news specials as well as a Netflix doc before the final verdict was even delivered. Insiders tell Deadline that Brownstone had been developing the project for some time and in recent months had started putting the package together, starting first by tapping Noble as showrunner. Once the trial ended this past spring they began packaging the remaining elements with Kelley ‚Äî who has delivered some of the best courtroom drama in the past 30 years ‚Äî boarding as a producer along with Wondery and Law & Order. RELATED: Elizabeth Banks On Doing It All From Acting In ‚ÄòThe Better Sister' To Hosting ‚ÄòPress Your Luck' And Directing ‚ÄòCocaine Bear' ‚Äì The Actor's Side The series marks a reunion for Banks and Prime Video, who just worked together on series The Better Sister, which earned Banks some of the best reviews of her career. She also recently was seen in the FX series Mrs. America. Noble most recently worked on the HBO Max series The Sex Lives of College Girls and prior to that served as a writer on Never Have I Ever and Brooklyn Nine-Nine. Kelley is coming off another hit courtroom drama, Presumed Innocent for Apple, which has several Emmy nominations including Best Actor for Jake Gyllenhaal. Wondery is also coming off an Emmy-nominated series with Dying for Sex. They are also the producers behind Dr. Death. Banks and Brownstone are repped by UTA, Untitled Entertainment and Johnson Shapiro Slewett & Kole. Noble is repped by WME and Hansen Jacobsen. Kelley is repped by CAA. ¬∑ Get our Breaking News Alerts and Keep your inbox happy. Comments On Deadline Hollywood are monitored. Todd Haynes' Previously Shuttered Gay Romance ‚ÄòDe Noche' Being Revived With Pedro Pascal Circling
Source: Deadline    Published: 2025-08-27 16:10:00

By Anthony D'Alessandro Editorial Director/Box Office Editor EXCLUSIVE: Todd Haynes' gay romance De Noche, which shut down about a year ago, is being revived, with Pedro Pascal circling. According to sources, the plan is for this feature to get up and running in the New Year in Guadalajara, Mexico and a lot of that is being worked around the 4x Emmy nominated actor's busy schedule from now into 2026. This is a great ray of sunshine for a production which was long considered kaput after Oscar winner Joaquin Phoenix left the production after reportedly being a no-show on set for two weeks prior to its unplugging. Vachon has said publicly that Phoenix brought the project to Killer Films which has a long history making LGBTQ fare. It was never known exactly why Joker Oscar winner Phoenix departed De Noche. Vachon waved off gossip at last year's San Sebastian Film Festival and said that it was a ‚Äútragedy‚Äù that the Haynes film fell apart. Related Stories News Hollywood Luminaries Get Behind Gaza Movie 'The Voice Of Hind Rajab' Ahead Of Venice World Premiere News 'The Last of Us' Stars & Creators Break Down Their Most Shocking Season 2 Scenes Pascal would join Danny Ramirez who was originally attached to the project. They'll play two men in love who leave Los Angeles for Mexico, the feature set in the 1930s. Christine Vachon and Pamela Koffler's Killer Films is producing. Killer recently worked with Pascal on A24's summer romantic comedy Materialists ($85M worldwide). Watch on Deadline Vachon also has a long working relationship with Haynes, producing the Oscar nominated filmmaker's canon including his 1991 directorial debut Poison, Safe (1995), Velvet Goldmine (1998), Far From Heaven (2002), I'm Not There (2007) and Carol (2015). Haynes was nominated for original screenplay at the Oscars in 2003 for his Julianne Moore movie Far From Heaven. Pascal is nominated at this year's Emmys for HBO's The Last of Us in the Best Actor Drama Series category. It's his second Emmy nom for the show in that category. He was also nominated for The Last of Us in Actor TV Drama at the 2024 Golden Globe Awards. Pascal is repped by CAA and Jackoway, Austen, Tyerman, etc. Haynes is repped by CAA, Cinetic Media, and Sloss Eckhouse Dasti Haynes LawCo. Get our Breaking News Alerts and Keep your inbox happy. ‚ÄòMother' Review: Noomi Rapace Leads Uneven Mother Teresa Drama with a Fine Mix of Austerity and Doubt
Source: IndieWire    Published: 2025-08-27 16:00:00

By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. Portraying saintliness is not a hagiographic directive, thankfully, in ‚ÄúMother,‚Äù Macedonian director Teona Strugar Mitevska's narrative of seven crucial days in the life of a 37-year-old Mother Teresa. Undue reverence was a charge levied against William Riead's ‚ÄúThe Letters,‚Äù the last major narrative fiction about the globally beloved Albanian-born Catholic nun who was granted sainthood nearly two decades after she passed in 1997, a delay Mitevska's feminist Teresa, a half century earlier, would have deemed unsurprisingly late. As she tells off a cherished male ally in an early scene, the world is run by ‚Äúmen, men, and men.‚Äù Related Stories Todd Haynes' Gay Romance That Collapsed After Joaquin Phoenix Exit Could Be Revived with Pedro Pascal ‚ÄòThe Toxic Avenger' Could Have Gone the Way of ‚ÄòBatgirl' ‚Äî Instead, It Might Be the Next ‚ÄòTerrifier'-Sized Hit However, due to uneven writing (Mitevska co-wrote the script with Goce Smilevski and Elma Tagaragic) that still does well to be concretely founded on interviews Mitevska conducted more than 15 years ago for an unreleased documentary ‚ÄúTeresa and I,‚Äù ‚ÄúMother‚Äù is on a mission that, its bold stylistic flourishes notwithstanding, isn't ultimately forceful or persuasive. In great part this is because the internal turmoil that we are led to believe the central characters harbor don't always inform the interpersonal confessions of which audiences can infer on their own. What does come through is Noomi Rapace's accessible interpretation of Teresa, with a punk rock alter-ego ‚Äî if not a dragon tattoo ‚Äî that delights even if it is discordant, and her charged, platonic yet intimate relationship with Sister Agnieszka, played by Dutch actor Sylvia Hoek (‚ÄúBlade Runner 2049‚Äù) who excels in shouldering the burden of the film's dramatic thrust. Popular on IndieWire Seven chapters in descending order structure the movie's story as a countdown of hiccups, indignations, and even a hallucination, a day each in a pivotal week that will determine Teresa's destiny. When the film opens, Teresa has been the Mother Superior of the Calcutta chapter of the Sisters of Loreto congregation since a decade earlier but feels she has outgrown her usefulness to the four-century-old institution. She is anxiously waiting to hear back from the Vatican regarding her application to start her own order, a privilege rarely granted to women. It has been a year since India's independence from the British, but to Mother, the suffering was equally immense before or after the country received its tumultuous nationhood. The most vulnerable ‚Äî starving children, people afflicted with leprosy, and pregnant women without the remotest possibility of healthcare ‚Äî always needed tending to; that colonial reality was intact. In fact, Mother feels she can save millions of more lives if only the Vatican recognized her plan. Credit to the filmmaker that she does not indulge in the poverty porn which many rightfully accuse other popular films by white directors set in India (looking at you, ‚ÄúSlumdog Millionaire‚Äù). Mitevska does conform though to the popular imagination of the extreme devotion exhibited by Saint Teresa towards the downtrodden. In one visceral scene of complex dignity, Mother removes maggots from a living man's rotting flesh. The macro 20th century Western rhetoric about Catholic charity can surely be critiqued for not engaging with the driving ideological role of caste, but that is not the interest of nor the purview of this film. Instead, a poignant conflict between the two nuns is. Mother's turbulent self-examination is incited by the revelation of Sister Agnieszka's pregnancy in the film's first Act. We've barely registered Agnieszka as a major character until then, just the hint that she is Mother's chosen successor (her ‚Äúnumber one‚Äù) should the Vatican honor her plea. In their first scene, there's playful banter as they move furniture and debate the virtue of not being attached to spaces and objects, even as Mother casually confides in Sister that she ‚Äúlost a child today.‚Äù Later, as the two mull over a handwritten constitution of best practices, which include wearing simple cotton and visiting family once every 10 years, emergencies be damned, Sister is compelled to share her secret. In an instance of the film's many calculated if stirring framing choices, Mitevska and DP Virginie Saint Martin cover half the frame entirely with the back of Mother's black veil, allowing us to focus on Hoeks' face as she utters the word ‚Äúpregnant.‚Äù Rapace's response externalizes four different beats, from a snort to a tear, astonishment to anger. The film's docufiction-like honesty is the most conspicuous here: to imagine that the Mother Teresa whom the world knows mostly as a faultless octogenarian might have as a younger woman had similar intense moments of extreme conflicting emotions is humanizing, and lovely. Here at least, we are in a position to know and feel both women's pain. Despite this build up in Chapters Seven and Six, the remaining five chapters don't always allow us to comprehend the warring impulses between the women. Sister confronts Mother about knowing what it means to fall in love; the use of a representation of a feminine depiction of God to cover Sister's face comes across more as a forced visual device than as a character's belief that earthly love can approach the divine. A dining room scene which Sister vigorously enters while in some sort of trance doesn't seem to jostle the other sisters who are not privy to the blasphemous situation. Several heated discussions on abortion, which should be fascinating as clues to the state of the debate in the 40s, feel didactic. Particularly, one later sequence, set jubilantly to ‚ÄúHard Rock Hallelujah‚Äù and which Mitevska heavily adorns with surrealism, is jarringly sudden because there's little evidence that Mother's dialectic with Sister would engender the radical doubt posited within Mother. Thus a lot of the narrative believability of the main characters' dilemmas doesn't always land. By contrast, Mother's exchanges with Father Friedrich (Nikola Ristanovski), the film's key supporting character, often work, because they appear to possess the sibling-like affection that Mother insists to a rumor mongering older nun they have. Also admirable are other craft elements, notably the camera movement in two interior rotundas to capture the characters spiraling; the lighting of somber dough making scenes; and the use of songs of faith towards solemn worldbuilding, like when the Sisters cut the hair of lachrymose inductees. As cinematic tapestry, Mitevska's cloistered film does feel cut from the cloth of Calcutta in 1948 and from the Catholic missionary work one attributes to that time. One could argue that for a film about the cataclysms in the corridors of faith, there's few leaps of transcendence in ‚ÄúMother.‚Äù However, the film isn't primarily about that. Mitevska wants to tell a tale about two women who try to find common ground, even friendship, despite being on different paths. Mitevska also refuses to sanctify Mother Teresa more than necessary, instead portraying her as a strict disciplinarian who believed in organizational practicality as much as in the inherent holiness of children. As for transcendence, there's a set of scenes when one character unexpectedly adorns red while another lines of blue. Not quite catharsis but a change in face of what we laypeople would call trauma. Minor transformations such as these help canonize a grounded if fairly flawed drama. ‚ÄúMother‚Äù opened the Orrizonti section at the 2025 Venice Film Festival. It is currently seeking U.S. distribution. Want to stay up to date on IndieWire's film reviews and critical thoughts? Subscribe here to our newly launched newsletter, In Review by David Ehrlich, in which our Chief Film Critic and Head Reviews Editor rounds up the best new reviews and streaming picks along with some exclusive musings ‚Äî all only available to subscribers. By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Boosie Badazz Plea Deal Explained: Feds Reveal Terms Rapper Accepted to End Gun Case
Source: Billboard    Published: 2025-08-27 15:25:13

A month after the rapper said he was "tired of fighting," the specifics of his plea deal are now public. By Bill Donahue Federal prosecutors have revealed the terms rapper Boosie Badazz's plea deal in his gun possession case ‚Äì including his recommended prison sentence and new details about his alleged misconduct. A month after Boosie (Torence Hatch) said he'd take a deal because he was ‚Äútired of fighting,‚Äù the rapper appeared in a San Diego federal courtroom Tuesday to formally plead guilty ‚Äì and the feds disclosed the specific terms of the deal. In return for Boosie pleading guilty to a single count of illegal gun ownership, prosecutors agreed to drop a second gun charge and ask for just a two-year prison sentence, far less than the maximum fifteen-year sentence the rapper was facing if convicted. Trending on Billboard They also revealed new details about the case against him ‚Äì including that he purchased the Glock and ‚ÄúHellcat‚Äù handguns in Georgia and flew with them to San Diego on a Delta Air Lines flight the same day that he was arrested during a traffic stop. ‚ÄúNeither the Glock, the Hellcat, nor the ammunition were manufactured in California,‚Äù the feds wrote in new court documents, obtained by Billboard. ‚ÄúTherefore, by the mere presence in San Diego, [the guns] traveled in and affected interstate commerce.‚Äù Prosecutors also said in the new filings that they would not seek a monetary fine on top of the prison sentence, citing Boosie's ‚Äúlimited financial prospects.‚Äù An attorney for the rapper did not immediately return a request for comment on Wednesday. Boosie was first charged in June 2023 with being a felon in possession of a firearm ‚Äì meaning he violated a federal law that prohibits people with felony convictions from owning guns. The rapper had previous been convicted of drug charges in 2011. The details of his arrest raised eyebrows. Local authorities spotted him with a handgun tucked into his waistband because they were monitoring the Instagram feed of a ‚Äúknown gang member.‚Äù After switching to Boosie's account, police then used a helicopter to track him in an allegedly gang-associated neighborhood of San Diego. After a traffic stop, prosecutors said he was found with a matching black pistol in the vehicle. The case has been anything but straightforward. State prosecutors initially charged him over the traffic stop, but then quickly dropped the case. Minutes after they did so, Boosie was arrested at the courthouse by federal prosecutors over the same incident. Then in July 2024, he was briefly saved by the Second Amendment. A judge dismissed the charges because an appeals court had ruled it unconstitutional to charge nonviolent convicts with felon-in-possession. Boosie left the courthouse in tears that day, according to Courthouse News: ‚ÄúNinety percent of people thought I was going to prison, but God had a different plan.‚Äù The respite was short-lived: Prosecutors quickly refiled the case with small changes, and a higher appeals court panel later overturned the gun-control ruling that might have helped him. The new case was proceeding toward an eventual jury trial when the plea agreement was reached earlier this month. Boosie announced the move on Instagram, saying he had ‚Äútalked to my family‚Äù and ‚Äúthis is the right decision.‚Äù ‚ÄúJUST ACCEPTED A PLEA FROM THE FEDERAL GOVERNMENT ON MY GUN CASE,‚Äù Boosie posted on X at the time. ‚ÄúI THOUGHT THIS CASE WAS OVER N I WAS GOING TO GET ON WITH MY LIFE BUT ‚ÄòGOD DONT MAKE MISTAKES' N IM TIRED OF FIGHTING!!‚Äù Under the terms of the plea deal revealed Tuesday, prosecutors will also recommend three years of supervised release after Boosie completes his prison sentence. Boosie can ask for less than two years in prison, and the government can oppose that request. A sentencing hearing is currently scheduled for November. Daily newsletters straight to your inbox Send us a tip using our anonymous form. A daily briefing on what matters in the music industry Send us a tip using our anonymous form. Billboard is a part of Penske Media Corporation. ¬© 2025 Billboard Media, LLC. All Rights Reserved.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


‚ÄòMother' Review: A Magnetic Noomi Rapace Plays Young Mother Teresa in a Stylistically Spiky Period Piece
Source: The Hollywood Reporter    Published: 2025-08-27 15:22:11

Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter Premiering in the Horizons section at Venice, Macedonian writer-director Teona Strugar Mitevska's film portrays the Albanian nun known mostly for her work with the poorest in India. By Leslie Felperin Contributing Film Critic Mother Teresa (1910-1997), the ethnically Albanian nun born in what is now known as North Macedonia and whose name has become a synonym for saintly goodness, was officially canonized in 2016, mostly for her missionary work with the poorest of the poor in Kolkata, India. But she continues to be a controversial figure, loved and worshipped by many Catholics but reviled by others who accuse her of hypocrisy and cruelty. Her most eloquent critic, the journalist Christopher Hitchens, once wrote that she ‚Äúwas not a friend of the poor. She was a friend of poverty.‚Äù And that was one of his kinder aper√ßus. Related Stories Movies Inside 'Megadoc': How Francis Ford Coppola Made Mike Figgis an Offer He Couldn't Refuse Movies Venice vs. Cannes: Who's Winning the Festival Fight for Oscar Supremacy? Macedonian writer-director Teona Strugar Mitevska (The Happiest Man in the World) clearly feels a kinship with her countrywoman. With Mother, partly inspired by Alexander Sokurov's offbeat portraits of Hitler (Moloch) and Lenin (Taurus), Mitevska threads the dirty needle with a decidedly non-hagiographic portrait of Teresa as a youngish mother superior in 1948 when she was about to leave her original order, the Sisters of Loreto, to start up her own outfit, the Missionaries of Charity. With crucial assistance from lead Noomi Rapace, in sterling form here with a coiled, subtle performance, Mother limns a Teresa whose stern expressions barely conceal the rolling boil of ambition, passionate attachments and religious fervor bubbling inside her. Mother The Bottom Line Neither holy perfect nor a god-awful mess. Venue: Venice Film Festival (Horizons)Cast: Noomi Rapace, Sylvia Hoeks, Nikola Ristanovski, Ekin Corapci, Marijke Pinoy, Akshay Kapoor, Amrita ChattopadhyayDirector: Teona Strugar MitevskaScreenwriters: Goce Smilevski, Teona Strugar Mitevska, Elma Tataragic 1 hour 44 minutes Partly informed by Mitevska's own research for her 2000 documentary Teresa and I, Mother also suggests Teresa might have been a less-than-ideal line manager, prone to capricious power games with the nuns working under her. At worst, she comes across as spiteful and cruel to those who disappoint her, such as her prot√©g√©e Sister Agnieszka (Sylvia Hoeks), who unwisely gets herself knocked up. Mitevska's attempt to expose some of the hidden warts underneath the shellacked saintly image of Teresa is punchy and Mother's whimsical touches, like the use of hard-rocking guitar shreds on the soundtrack and spooky dream sequences, add edge. Those hoping for a more thorough dismantling of the Mother Teresa shrine of popular imagination will be disappointed that the screenplay, credited to Goce Smilevski, Mitevska and previous collaborator Elma Tataragic, doesn't play rougher. But such is the fashion these days with filmmakers who, despite their known leftist allegiances, bend over backwards to be balanced when depicting the likes of Donald Trump (The Apprentice), Dick Cheney (Vice) or Boris Johnson (British TV's This England). As with those latter films, Mother works as well as it does thanks to the charismatic central performance. That's crucial because, although the screenplay is grounded in biographical research, Mitevska eschews expository monologues that might fill in backstory. The script even sprinkles the dialogue with unfinished sentences, frequent interruptions and teasing lacunae, allowing viewers to fill in blanks as they wish. For example, it's never made clear whether anything palpable happened between Teresa and her confessor Father Friedrich (Nikola Ristanovski), although at one point a disgruntled nun hisses a rumor that they were lovers. You'd think, given Teresa's dedication to chastity and staunch belief that any kind of contraception let alone abortion is an abomination, that it's unlikely she and Friedrich ever got busy knocking sandals. But then again, maybe that's exactly why she's so uptight about conceptions that aren't immaculate? Either way, the pair's intense conversations feel freighted with feelings, especially when it comes to discussing who will replace Teresa as the Sisters of Loreto's mother superior if and when the word comes through from the Pope granting her permission to found a new order. Friedrich favors gentle-mannered Agnieszka, a Pole who escaped the Holocaust back in Europe, and a gifted teacher of children. With tendrils of blonde hair always trying to escape her wimple, there's an ineluctable sensuality about Agnieszka. It's hinted that Teresa may see something of a younger version of herself in Agnieszka, which may be why she so fiercely rejects her when Agnieszka reveals her pregnancy. After Agnieszka visits the local Indian doctor (Akshay Kapoor) to inquire about an abortion, Teresa predictably flames out and locks Agnieszka in her room, telling the other nuns that she's suffering from gastric complaints. All this unfolds while the days count down, flagged by bold onscreen graphics, to the Day Zero when Teresa will get her papal dispensation and leave the convent to start her new order. She's already thought out how they will wear simple white and blue saris like the local women, how much leave they will be allowed to go home and visit their family (precious little), and how they will devote themselves to ministering to the poor, the leprous and the outcast. There will be no comfy whitewashed buildings like the Sisters of Lareto enjoy, or impromptu ball games in the courtyard. Fun is not high on Teresa's agenda. Despite the austerity of her ambitions, there are moments of lush imagination that leaven the tone somewhat, like a dream sequence in which Teresa, furiously making bread in the middle of the night, is teased by an impish child. Soon, she imagines her sisters floating as if on roller skates or wheeled dollies through moonlit corridors while electric guitars and vocalists wail away like heavy metal wraiths. It's not what you'd expect from a film about Mother Teresa, and Hitchens surely wouldn't have approved of anything that risked making her seem cooler and hipper than she was. Mitevska clearly has no such scruples. Perhaps the desire to make Teresa vivid to viewers today would explain the numerous possibly intentional anachronisms in the costuming and design, such as the use of zippers on the nuns' robes, t-shirts on the Kolkata extras advertising contemporary brands like YouTube, and the unmistakable modernity of the Indian locations used, especially at the very end. Or maybe we're to infer that we're seeing Teresa's saintly ghost walking through a contemporary street market. If so, the theology is a little wonky but the filmmaking has an undoubtedly visionary swagger. Sign up for THR news straight to your inbox every day Sign up for THR news straight to your inbox every day Subscribe for full access to The Hollywood Reporter Send us a tip using our anonymous form.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


‚ÄòThe Toxic Avenger' Could Have Gone the Way of ‚ÄòBatgirl' ‚Äî Instead, It Might Be the Next ‚ÄòTerrifier'-Sized Hit
Source: IndieWire    Published: 2025-08-27 15:00:00

By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. First, some numbers. The first ‚ÄúToxic Avenger‚Äù film, a Troma classic directed by the inimitable Lloyd Kaufman, arrived in theaters in 1984, eventually spawning three sequels, a stage musical, a Marvel comic book series, a video game, and an animated television series. Not too shabby! Of course, with legs like that, reboot talk couldn't be too far off. And reboot talk did indeed happen, in 2010, in 2013, and in 2016. But it took until 2018 for anyone ‚Äî including Kaufman and Legendary Entertainment, who had just snapped up the first film's reboot rights ‚Äî to really dig into what a new Toxie could be, announcing a planned reboot and a search for writers. One year later, filmmaker Macon Blair came on board as both writer and director, after initially being picked to write the script. Related Stories ‚ÄòNuremberg' Teaser: Russell Crowe and Rami Malek Engage in a Psychological Duel in the Aftermath of World War II Venice Jury Prez Alexander Payne Avoids Making Statement on Festival's Reaction to War in Gaza Another year after that, Blair set Peter Dinklage as the film's star, reimagined as a scrappy janitor trying to hold his life together, both before and after he falls into a tank of toxic waste, the product of his very evil boss (Kevin Bacon). By 2021, Blair was shooting the film. In 2023, it finally premiered, hitting the genre circuit hard and to understandably pleased reviews. And then? Nada. More numbers: it is now 2025, two years after the film first premiered, seven years after what would become this version was first announced, 15 years since a reboot was murmured about, and 41 years since Kaufman's original was first released. So, is there a world where this film, one so long hoped-for and chatted-about, didn't get an actual release? As Blair told IndieWire during a recent interview, oh, yes. But that's not the world he wanted to live in ‚Äî think of it as ‚ÄúBatgirl‚Äù Land ‚Äî and his fears over the film not getting released (or not getting the released in a fun, splashy way) were laid to rest when Cineverse picked up the film in 2025. The ‚ÄúTerrifier‚Äù crew is a smart fit for this kind of film, something fun and genre-focused, best in a theater among pals, and definitely better unrated, as the film will arrive (finally!) this week in theaters. And, never fear, Blair is already at work on his next movie, ‚ÄúThe Shitheads,‚Äù which he described as a road movie that is ‚Äúmuch more tonally in the spirit of the first movie that I made, much more in the real world than the cartoon world of Toxie.‚Äù That film stars Toxie himself, Peter Dinklage, plus Dave Franco, O'Shea Jackson Jr., and Karen Shipka. It won't take as long as his ‚ÄúToxie,‚Äù that's for sure. The following interview has been edited and condensed for clarity and length. IndieWire: It's been a long road for you and the film. Macon Blair: Yes, [it was] certainly nerve-wracking when it's sitting on the shelf. I can't help but think of ‚ÄúBatgirl‚Äù and ‚ÄúCoyote vs. Acme‚Äù and things like that. That's not Legendary, because Legendary were down to rock and roll from the beginning, but there's layers and layers above them. You never know who's going to look at a spreadsheet and be like, ‚ÄúThis shit is more valuable as this.‚Äù But I also had a lot of faith that the Legendary people were always really pushing it, and they never took their foot off the gas. With the benefit of hindsight and having ended up at Cineverse, if [we had to wait] a couple of years to land at a place like that, who is not interested in dumping it to a streamer and they seem to really like it and they're releasing it in that spirit, then I would've been happy to wait a little longer for this outcome. It's turned out really wonderfully. There must have been a point where it seemed like this wasn't going to come out. Yeah, I worried that there was a possibility of that, but I also worried that it would just vanish into a streaming netherworld. So many people on the crew and on the cast worked really, really hard on this, they put their faith in me, and I wanted them to feel like that they didn't make a bad choice and be like, ‚ÄúI fucking knew it.‚Äù I want their hard work to be rewarded and get the proper spotlight that it deserves and get them to get some shout-outs. I'm glad that they get to see it and they can show it to their friends and family and feel like it's an actual thing and not just some lost cause that vanished somewhere. It already feels like a victory. The film premiered at Fantastic Fest in 2023, then you went on to Beyond Fest, Sitges, and Edinburgh. And then it felt like we heard nothing about next steps. It was like we had Fantastic Fest and Beyond Fest in close proximity, so there was this pop of, ‚ÄúOoh.‚Äù Those audiences are predisposed to this like movie, so we were maybe getting graded on a curve there, but that's OK. But still, it had momentum coming out of that. At the time, my understanding is the streamers were not doing as much and things were contracting all over the place, and if something was perceived to be like, ‚ÄúI'm not sure if this is going to be a crowd-pleaser,‚Äù then it was risky. And somewhere along the lines, an idea got out there that it was too gross or something, and that was the reason. But it's not. It's not that gross at all. I feel like sometimes people think, oh, this is a good way to hype people up. ‚ÄúIt's so gross. You're not going to believe this! You gotta see it!‚Äù I'm very gun-shy about that kind of thing. There's ‚ÄúGame of Thrones‚Äù where people are getting ripped apart, there's TV shows that are completely savage, and there's movies like ‚ÄúTerrifier‚Äù that Cineverse is doing. And just as an audience member, not as somebody who made the movie, if somebody's like, ‚ÄúYou're not going to believe this shit,‚Äù and it's below that, then your expectations are calibrated in a wrong way and it affects the whole thing. Whenever anybody asks me about it, I'm very quick to be like, ‚ÄúIt's not that gory.‚Äù It's a comedy. It's not a horror movie. It's not a splatter movie, for sure. It's a goofy comedy that happens to have a little bit of blood in the fringes. As an audience member, what was your entry into ‚ÄúThe Toxic Avenger‚Äù and to the wider Tromaverse? I'm not an expert by any means, but I did see [‚ÄúThe Toxic Avenger‚Äù], the original, at a very young age. The sense of humor ‚Äî which is juvenile and silly, and I say that with nothing but affection ‚Äî as a 12-year-old, it's exactly right on the money, so I was like, this is fucking hilarious. It also seemed to be, with the exception of maybe something like ‚ÄúNight of the Living Dead,‚Äù it was the first thing that I could remember watching that really seemed handmade. Movies [to me] were Hollywood, and this was like, ‚ÄúOh, this is just dudes. They just got a camera and did it with homemade makeup, it seemed like.‚Äù That was hugely inspiring. The guys that I was hanging out with at that time, there was a group of about six of us ‚Äî Jeremy Saulnier was one of them ‚Äî and we had gotten our hands on a VHS camera, so the idea of just making movies in your own neighborhood with your own resources suddenly became [real]. That part was hugely inspirational, more so than the content of the movie. That's what really drove us forward. It was never like, ‚ÄúOne day I'm going to make a ‚ÄòToxie.'‚Äù It never crossed my mind as even a possibility, but when they started soliciting writers to do a version of this new one, it did occur to me that there could be something fun in the idea of going back to the type of movie that we were making when we were 12, but with the machinery of an actual studio behind it. That's what I pitched to them. It wasn't like it went from there to production, it incrementally became a writing job and incrementally became a directing job. It took some time to get there, but that was the genesis. I see your emotional spirit in the movie. There is a real sweetness in there, while also acknowledging there are a lot of things that are super fucked up in the world. In a weird way, even in the original film, for all the running children over with cars and everything that goes on, there's a sweet element to it. [Laughs] Maybe it's just in the way they're made. But that was one of the things that I talked to Legendary about. Certainly, we'll do the gross stuff and we'll do the blood and guts, but I don't want it to feel mean. I want it to feel sweet. The other thing was, in the original movie, they did the horny teenager who's trying to get girls and he gets picked on. They'd done that so singularly that I was just like, if we literally do that, then it really does beg the question of, why are you doing it at all? Which is already going to hang over the whole thing anyway. I felt like the best way to answer that question is to take the vibe of the original, you've got the classic character with the tutu and the mop and the eye, and give people what they expect in that regard, but have the character be somebody new with a new emotional thing going on. I know we're all sick to death of the word ‚Äútimely,‚Äù but that's stuff in there too. You have this entire sequence about a bunch of idiots who freak out because the local fast food joint, which used to be called ‚ÄúMr. Meat,‚Äù is now called ‚ÄúMiss Meat.‚Äù You've got to remember, that was written so long ago. That was written in 2019, 2020, which means that that shit is like, it's never not timely. How to be delicate about this? As our American headlines developed, I was watching like, ‚ÄúOh, shit, some people are unironically saying the exact same stuff.‚Äù There was a part of me that was didn't want to be that on the nose, and it's unfortunate that it has become that on the nose. But on the other hand, the idea of fucking boneheads ruining it for everybody else is also timeless. We can talk about that in the '90s, we can talk about that in the '50s. We could talk about that any old time and it's going to be like, oh, that's what it's about. Rich people victimizing poor people and the world. Classic! Classic. What is it? Is it the '20s? I don't know.1920s or 2020s, pick either one. It may not seem this way, but it really was not being like, ‚ÄúI'm going to make a point about something!‚Äù It was just like, ‚ÄúWhat is a universal villain that can make it really difficult for Winston?‚Äù And so it was those larger metaphoric things for him to fight against. It was just a thing to put in front of him so that he could battle it, but it was not meant to be like, ‚Äúand also this will have a message.‚Äù The people with a big factory with big vats of toxic sludge, they're always going to be the bad guy. Part of it was like, it's low-hanging fruit because who's going to be like, ‚ÄúNo, wait, but the guy that's dumping vats of shit into the river, he's got a point too‚Äù? It was just like, ‚ÄúWhat's the biggest thing that a powerless outsider could have to contend with?‚Äù So it was more of a dramatic choice than a, I don't know, cultural choice, if that makes sense. You also include the dramatic choice of giving Elijah Wood's character what is, essentially, his own group of nitwit heavies who do his bidding, sort of if Insane Clown Posse were a bunch of criminal morons. A lot of the things in this movie ‚Äî and some of it is sound design, some of it is costume, some of it is characters ‚Äî are just, for better or worse, [asking] ‚Äúwouldn't it be funny if,‚Äù and then allowing that to get out of control. Suddenly, you're committed to it and then you're like, ‚ÄúWell, now we have to give these people dialogue, and now they're actual characters.‚Äù It was just like, if a band like Slipknot ‚Äî who I'm sure are perfectly nice people in real life, but their stage presence is sinister and scary, or KISS or Alice Cooper or Screamin' Jay, whatever ‚Äî what if their stage show was [real], and they actually are devil-worshiper psychopaths? A very rudimentary joke. Just in talking about it with the producers, they were like, ‚ÄúWhat do you think about the bad guys?‚Äù I was like, ‚ÄúWell, I think it's like if the Insane Clown Posse was actually insane.‚Äù And everybody in the room laughed and I was like, ‚ÄúWell, fuck. I guess here we are.‚Äù And there's something about casting Elijah in that role, where he is part of this bad family, he's a bad guy, but he has such an inherent sweetness to him, so that when he maybe makes some better choices later, you're like, ‚ÄúYeah, I buy that.‚Äù I wrote that role for him, because, yeah, I'm fond of that guy. It was just a matter of coming up with the idea of him. What I said was, ‚ÄúIt could be like a Peter Sellers-type role where your name will be on the poster and everyone's going to know that you're in the movie, but setting that aside, if they didn't know you're in the movie and they saw you come on the screen, they might not know that you're in the movie.‚Äù That was appealing, and also to make him the opposite of Kevin Bacon, who is the golden Adonis and [Wood is playing] this twisted goblin. I was like, I bet he is going to say yes to this, and he very quickly was like, ‚ÄúOh, I'd love to do it.‚Äù So, what is the process of getting Kevin Bacon to say yes to this? I think he has had a much more interesting career than he gets credit for, he's made such interesting choices, and you tapped into that with this role. There was something there, that [he] is a legit American movie star, one of the few remaining American movie star types, and it was like, that would be fun to make him the ultimate, sinister bad guy. But also, the way people perceive him is, I don't think he gets credit as much as he deserves for how funny he is. I think he has a great sense of humor about himself and doesn't take himself too seriously. You think about ‚ÄúMystic River‚Äù and projects where he's more of a tough guy, and I was like, ‚ÄúThis could be an opportunity for him to go super silly.‚Äù Leslie Nielsen started out as heartthrob leading man and then became this comedy secret weapon. And it was remarkably easy. In fact, he said, and it does sound like I'm bragging, but I'm not, he said, ‚ÄúIt was a very easy yes.‚Äù I was prepared to be like, ‚ÄúOK, you read the script. It seems stupid. It's stupid on purpose, and here's why.‚Äù I didn't have to do any of that. He was like, ‚ÄúYeah, dude, let's talk about it. What do you think he wears?‚Äù And I was like, ‚ÄúOh, shit, we're already into that.‚Äù It was a very quick process. Not a lot of convincing at all. No convincing, actually. Peter is also a wonderful choice for this, but the role of Toxie is actually shared. After his transformation, Winston is played by Luisa Guerreiro in the suit, which is this wonderful, really emotional performance. Is that a practical thing? Did you only have Peter for a certain amount of time, or did he not want to get in the suit? It was a scheduling thing. We had to have that role cast in order to trigger everything else. I would've been fine if he wanted to do the costume, and I'm sure he would've been good with it too, but he had a window and was able to do that. So that was the way to make it work. We found Luisa the old-fashioned way, with auditions. She was really good at tumbling and stunts and stage fighting, she had a great physical reel, but then she did a dramatic read of some of Toxie's monologues and it was great. We were like, ‚ÄúOh, shit, she's going to be fantastic.‚Äù And there was a few little [comments], ‚ÄúBut one is a man and one is a woman.‚Äù I was like, ‚ÄúI don't give a fuck. It's going to be great. Don't worry about it.‚Äù And it was. She and Peter rehearsed a lot together. Peter performed the movie on video, so she had all these tapes of, ‚ÄúOh, these are his choices. This is how he pauses. This is what he does with his hand,‚Äù all that kind of thing. She memorized it. It was wild. What was great was, there was this one day where somebody came to set and didn't understand the process and they were like, ‚ÄúPeter's doing a great job.‚Äù We're like, ‚ÄúIt's not Peter.‚Äù Peter came back and did the voice later, but the hope is that it would be invisible. When was the first time you watched the movie with an audience? Was it at Fantastic Fest? The finished movie, yes, Fantastic Fest. We did one friends and family screening with some strangers, and then we did two recruited screenings, which are brutal, where it's all just strangers that came in. We had one on St. Patrick's Day in a suburb of Los Angeles, and a bunch of drunk people walk in with leprechaun hats on and they watched the first five minutes and were like, ‚ÄúWhat the‚Ä¶‚Äù Because they don't tell you what it is, it's just ‚Äúa movie.‚Äù They saw the opening scene and a third of them just left and I was like, ‚ÄúOh, my God, we're in trouble.‚Äù But those screenings, they did prove to be useful. There were some things that I pushed back on or whatever, editorially and how we were shaping the movie. Nothing major. It didn't become a different movie, but just some little surgical things here and there. It was a great learning experience, because I was really trying to stick to my guns and, ‚ÄúNo, this is the vision. This is the vision.‚Äù But as it turns out, when we made those changes, the audience was able to clock in a little bit better. It was a good lesson to, yes, sticking to your guns is good, but also listen to others. You end the movie in Marvel fashion, with a little line that ‚ÄúToxie will return ‚Ä¶ but only if this film makes a billion dollars.‚Äù Oh, you stayed until the very end. There's a constant running gag of townspeople that are not on camera that are commenting [throughout the film]. It's not in the script. I had two really great editors, Brett Bachman and James Thomas, and a lot of [making] the movie was, just trying to make each other laugh. ‚ÄúWouldn't it be funny if at this point somebody yelled something?‚Äù And then we record a line on a phone, and then it goes in the movie, and then it stays in the movie. The next thing you know, it's in the finished product. There's a lot of that. And that thing that you just mentioned was one of those where, we got to the end and we were like, ‚ÄúI don't know. What should we do?‚Äù All the files were being sent for finishing and we had one of the assistant editors make a graphic. We made it up in about two hours, and it was just everybody giggling. Not the text really, but the sound effects. ‚ÄúWhat would be funny? Let's do a little bike horn.‚Äù Everyone is so tired and it's very late at night, and everybody's a little punchy and not a lot of sleep, and so it doesn't take much for people to get the giggles. But once you get the giggles, it turns into, ‚ÄúPut it in the movie, put it in the movie,‚Äù and then it stays in the movie. Four years after wrapping the movie, two years after premiering it, the film is finally coming out. What are you expecting and hoping for? Cineverse has been going crazy. It's been really cool to see that without the massive financial resources of a Disney or something like that, where it's a lot of television commercials and traditional spreads of advertising, they've been really sharp with these interesting event things. Like, Toxie shows up at a parade or something, and then it gets talked about online as a means of getting the word out. They did similar stuff with the ‚ÄúTerrifier‚Äù movies, and were very successful with that. The hope is that same word of mouth, street level, getting the word out, it can be successful, too. For me, the movie coming out in theaters at all in the Year of Our Lord 2025 is a victory. Obviously, I want it to do really well, I want everybody to feel like that it can be correctly described as a success, but I don't know how to gauge that. I'm not under the hood with numbers of engagement and everything like that. I don't know how that works. I trust them to tell me if it's going well or not. They're very enthusiastic. They feel good about it, and they feel like it's got a really good shot at doing well, so we'll see what happens. Cineverse will release ‚ÄúThe Toxic Avenger‚Äù in theaters on Friday, August 29. By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. Taylor Swift & Travis Kelce's Engagement Announcement Breaks Instagram Record
Source: Billboard    Published: 2025-08-27 14:59:45

The post reached the milestone in just six hours. By Hannah Dailey Taylor Swift and Travis Kelce‚Äòs post on Instagram announcing their engagement got a lot of, well, engagement. According to data shared with Billboard on Wednesday (Aug. 27), Meta counts that the photos of the Kansas City Chiefs tight end proposing to the pop star have surpassed 1 million reposts on Instagram ‚Äî more than any other post has ever received on the platform. Even more impressive, the couple's announcement achieved that record in just six hours. The news comes after Billboard previously reported that the post had earned 14 million ‚Äúlikes‚Äù in just one hour. At press time, Instagram displays that it has surged past 29 million. If there was ever going to be a post that would garner such high stats, it's Swift and Kelce's. The duo's big reveal ‚Äî which they shared by writing, ‚ÄúYour English teacher and your gym teacher are getting married‚Äù ‚Äî sent the internet into an absolute frenzy, with fans flooding social media with messages of shock and congratulations. Even President Donald Trump got in on the action, setting aside his grievances with the 14-time Grammy winner to say during a cabinet meeting, ‚ÄúI think he's a great guy, and she's a terrific person, so I wish them a lot of luck.‚Äù Trending on Billboard The engagement comes after about two years of dating for Swift and the athlete, who popped the question two weeks prior to their Tuesday (Aug. 26) announcement, according to Kelce's dad, Ed. The lovebirds now have wedding planning to add to their busy schedules, which features the beginning of the Chiefs' football season on Sept. 5 and the release of the musician's new album, The Life of a Showgirl, on Oct. 3. Cradle of Filth Members Leave Band Over 'Unprofessional Behavior,' 'Low Pay,' and Ed Sheeran Collab
Source: Rolling Stone    Published: 2025-08-27 14:37:38

By Daniel Kreps Two members of the long-running metal band Cradle of Filth have abruptly left the group amid their current tour, citing ‚Äúunprofessional behavior‚Äù and a ‚Äúfoolish‚Äù collaboration with Ed Sheeran. Singer and keyboardist Zo√´ M. Federoff first announced her exit from the band earlier this week for ‚Äúpersonal reasons‚Äù; days later, Cradle of Filth revealed they were ‚Äúfiring‚Äù guitarist and Federoff's husband Marek ‚ÄúAshok‚Äù ≈†merda, who had been a member of Cradle of Filth since 2014, while Federoff joined in 2022. While fans initially speculated that a rift in Federoff and ≈†merda's marriage was to blame for their sudden departures, Federoff clarified on social media, ‚ÄúAshok isn't cheating. While the turmoil of being in the band has taken its toll on us, we remain very much certain that we love each other. Please be kind to my husband. He is a good man. We were already planning to leave the band later this year. Certain events have sped that up for me.‚Äù A post shared by Cradle of Filth (@cradleoffilth) Cradle of Filth frontman Dani Filth issued the band's statement regarding ≈†merda's firing ‚Äúeffective immediately‚Äù after ≈†merda initially told fans he would leave the group after their current South American tour. ‚ÄúWe simply do not feel like Cradle can provide for our future, and in fact hinders it. Among other reasons, it is a lot of work for relatively low pay, the stress is quite high, and we haven't felt for a while like this band actually prioritizing/caring about members. It has been years of unprofessional behavior from people above us that led to our decision,‚Äù ≈†merda wrote. A post shared by Marek SÃåmerda (@marek_ashok_smerda) ‚ÄúI have also asked all compositions of mine removed from upcoming releases including Ed Sheeran collab. This song feels like foolish clown antics for me at this point anyways ‚Äî first it was charity single for kids, then for profit single, then on next album, and now who knows and I just do not want to be involved anymore, no disrespect to Ed Sheeran.‚Äù Trending Stories Elon Musk Appears to Be Completely Addicted to Anime Gooner AI Slop Lil Nas X Breaks Silence on Arrest and Felony Charges: ‚ÄòThat Was F-cking Terrifying' Trump's Cabinet Meeting Was Stuffed With Flattery for Dear Leader Bruce Willis Is Living in a Separate Home Away From Family as Part of His Dementia Care (Rumors of the Sheeran/Cradle of Filth collaboration first emerged in 2022 after the pop singer revealed, ‚ÄúI was really into death metal as a kid. I listened to Cradle of Filth and Slipknot and all that stuff.‚Äù Dani Filth said earlier this year that the band recorded a collaborative track, but it didn't feature on their new album, The Screaming of the Valkyries.) The two members' departure coincided with the band's South American tour, which continued as scheduled on Tuesday in Montevideo, Uruguay. ‚ÄúDespite all attempts to illegally defame and derail the band, CRADLE OF FILTH WILL NOT cancel any of our South American shows, though fans will have to bear with us being a band with only one guitarist live, that is of course until Ashok's temporary replacement is flown out to join the tour in a few days time,‚Äù Dani Filth said in his statement. A replacement for Federoff was already installed in Cradle of Filth's ever-changing lineup. We want to hear it. Send us a tip using our anonymous form. Iceage's Elias R√∏nnenfelt Announces New Album Speak Daggers, Shares Video for New Song: Watch
Source: Pitchfork    Published: 2025-08-27 14:23:33

Iceage frontperson Elias R√∏nnenfelt has announced his second solo album, following last year's Heavy Glory. Speak Daggers arrives October 17, via Escho, and features reggae all-timers the Congos and Copenhagen artists Erika de Casier and Fine. Watch the Foushe√©-directed video for new single ‚ÄúUSA Baby,‚Äù which samples Bassekou Kouyate and Ngoni Ba's ‚ÄúMiri,‚Äù below. R√∏nnenfelt and Foushe√© recently linked up on ‚ÄúLittle Gods,‚Äù one of two songs R√∏nnenfelt recorded with Yung Lean, who operated under his Jonatan Leandoer96 alias. Since then, the Iceage man has reunited with his Lucre EP collaborators, Dean Blunt and Vegyn, for ‚ÄúTears on His Rings and Chains.‚Äù And for anyone curious about the Congos collaboration: It came about when R√∏nnenfelt visited the band in Jamaica a few years ago, an Escho representative told Pitchfork. Ben & Erin Napier Receive Heartwarming Support From Celebs & Fans After Massive Fire
Source: EntertainmentNow    Published: 2025-08-27 14:10:45

Ben and Erin Napier are feeling the love as fans and famous friends support them and their community through an extremely tough loss. On the morning of August 26, 2025, a massive fire broke out at the brand-new hotel the HGTV superstars were preparing to open with their tight-knit circle of friends in Laurel, Mississippi. Just days before, the Napiers and two other couples who are their dear friends and business partners ‚Äî Jim and Mallorie Rasberry (Jim is Erin's cousin, and Mallorie is her longtime bestie) and Josh and Emily Nowell ‚Äî had unveiled the Heirloom Hotel and shared the news of an upcoming HGTV show they'd been filming about the hotel. ‚ÄúToday feels like a funeral,‚Äù Erin wrote in an Instagram post on August 26, describing how they'd huddled with their friends that morning, and ‚Äúheld each other and watched while the brave fire fighters from the Laurel FD worked for hours to get it under control.‚Äù A post shared by Erin Napier (@erinapier) The Napiers, Rasberrys, and Nowells were showered with love and sympathy from HGTV stars and countless fans, many who feel like they know the other couples from their appearances on ‚ÄúHome Town.‚Äù ‚Äú100 Day Dream Home‚Äù star Brian Kleinschmidt wrote in the comment section of Erin's post, ‚ÄúThis breaks my heart. üôè I know how much hard work and passion went into this project. Thank God no one was hurt. Anything can be fixed‚Ä¶anyone can't be.‚Äù On a post about the fire on the Heirloom Hotel's account, Kleinschmidt also wrote, ‚ÄúWhat can Mika and I do to help? üôè‚Äù Hundreds of fans liked a comment from ‚ÄúFixer to Fabulous‚Äù star Jenny Marrs, who wrote, ‚ÄúOh Erin. I'm so so sorry. Praying right now for you all. üíîüôè‚Äù Many were also touched by a message from HGTV's Sarah Baeumler, who offered, ‚ÄúSo sorry üò¢ Sending thoughts and prayers to you and @theheirloom.us ‚ô•Ô∏è We can rebuild ‚Äì together ‚Äì as one @hgtv family.‚Äù One fan responded to Baeumler, ‚ÄúHow sweet of you to say ‚Äòwe' can rebuild. That just goes to show how much of a family you really are to each other!ü•π‚Äù Another replied, ‚ÄúYes, you have so much love around you and your town. I'm sure everyone would love to anything they could from fundraising or donating to buying Heirloom swag‚Äîanything we can do to help rebuild. We believe in the magic of Laurel and the love and strength of this community. ‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äù A post shared by The Heirloom (@theheirloom.us) As fans and friends flooded the Napiers with love, Erin asked that people also send love to their friends, who spearheaded the Heirloom Hotel project. Jim and Josh worked behind the scenes, and launched the ‚ÄúHeirloom‚Äù podcast in June (which Ben and Erin have both appeared on), while Mallorie ‚Äî who has appeared on many episodes of ‚ÄúHome Town‚Äù helping Erin with projects ‚Äî became the face of the hotel, overseeing much of its design and hospitality elements. In an Instagram Story on August 26, Erin wrote, ‚ÄúToday Laurel is grieving. My best friends and family are suffering. Their hotel, the @heirloom.us, burned this morning. Heap your love on the ones who have been building this for the last two years: @joshuanowell, @malraz, and my cousin Jim Rasberry.‚Äù On another Story, she shared Heirloom Hotel's post about the fire and wrote, ‚ÄúDown but not out.‚Äù The group's restoration of the Kress Building was going to be shown in a new HGTV spinoff series called ‚ÄúHome Town: Inn This Together.‚Äù According to HGTV press materials, they transformed the 25,000-square-foot space into a 30-room hotel with a cooking school, storefront, and all the quaint design features fans have come to love on ‚ÄúHome Town.‚Äù In her post, Erin wrote that she didn't know if fans would ‚Äúever get to see‚Äù the new show. But many begged for HGTV to air it and to help the Heirloom team rebuild, as Baeumler suggested. ‚ÄúPraying for you all for grace, peace and hope,‚Äù one follower wrote, ‚ÄúGod has a plan, he will provide. I am so sorry üòû. I do hope that @hgtv will still air the show. I was looking so forward to watching . ‚ù§Ô∏èüôè‚Äù Another chimed in, ‚Äúüôènoooo, this is crazy. üíî HGTV, HELP BRING THIS HOTEL BACK‚Äù The Laurel Leader-Call reported that the hotel went ‚Äúup in flames‚Äù after the ‚Äúblaze engulfed the former Kress Building‚Äù beginning around 5 a.m. The paper said it took several hours for firefighters from five different stations to get the fire under control, but no injuries were reported. Bruce Willis Is Living in a Separate Home Away From Family as Part of His Dementia Care
Source: Rolling Stone    Published: 2025-08-27 14:07:26

By Jon Blistein Bruce Willis is now living in a separate one-story home, away from his family, but with round-the-clock care, as part of his dementia treatment, the actor's wife, Emma Heming Willis, revealed in a new ABC special, Emma & Bruce Willis: The Unexpected Journey. Heming Willis said moving her husband into his own place was ‚Äúone of the hardest decisions‚Äù she's had to make as a caregiver. But, she added, she felt it was necessary to give Willis a home that was safe, quiet, and easy for him to get around. ‚ÄúI knew, first and foremost, Bruce would want that for our daughters,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúYou know, he would want them to be in a home that was more tailored to their needs, not his needs.‚Äù Another factor in moving Willis to a second home had to do with how his dementia had forced Heming Willis and the couple's two daughters, who are 13 and 11, to overhaul their own lives. For instance, Heming Willis worried that loud noises and chaotic scenes could trigger agitation in her husband, leading her to cut down on playdates and sleepovers for their daughters. ‚ÄúI didn't know if parents would feel comfortable leaving their child at our home, so, again, not only was I isolated, I isolated our whole family,‚Äù Heming Willis said. ‚ÄúYou know, the girls were isolated too, and that was by design; I was doing that. It was a hard time. It was a really hard time.‚Äù Willis' second home is close to where Heming Willis and their daughters still live, and all three still see Willis frequently, often for breakfast and dinner. ‚ÄúIt is a house that is filled with love and warmth and care and laughter,‚Äù Heming Willis said. Trending Stories Elon Musk Appears to Be Completely Addicted to Anime Gooner AI Slop Lil Nas X Breaks Silence on Arrest and Felony Charges: ‚ÄòThat Was F-cking Terrifying' Trump's Cabinet Meeting Was Stuffed With Flattery for Dear Leader Bruce Willis Is Living in a Separate Home Away From Family as Part of His Dementia Care Willis was diagnosed with frontotemporal dementia two years ago. Elsewhere in the interview, Heming Willis said the actor is still in ‚Äúreally great overall,‚Äù but acknowledged, ‚ÄúIt's just his brain that is failing him.‚Äù She added, ‚ÄúThe language is going, and you know, we've learned to adapt. And we have a way of communicating with him, which is just a different, a different way.‚Äù We want to hear it. Send us a tip using our anonymous form. Rolling Stone is a part of Penske Media Corporation. ¬© 2025 Rolling Stone, LLC. All rights reserved.

‚ÄòNuremberg' Teaser: Russell Crowe and Rami Malek Engage in a Psychological Duel in the Aftermath of World War II
Source: IndieWire    Published: 2025-08-27 14:00:00

By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy. We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply. The aftermath of World War II will be on full display this fall in ‚ÄúNuremberg,‚Äù a new historical thriller from writer/director James Vanderbilt. The film, which stars Rami Malek and Russell Crowe, is about an American psychiatrist (Malek) tasked with probing the mind of infamous Nazi leader Hermann G√∂ring (Crowe) before he is prosecuted for his war crimes in the Nuremberg Trials, is set to premiere at the Toronto International Film Festival before Sony Pictures Classics gives it an awards-friendly November release date. IndieWire can exclusively debut the film's second teaser, which shows the mental warfare taking place between the two men as they prepare for a trial that would shape the post-war international order for the rest of the 20th century. Related Stories Venice Jury Prez Alexander Payne Avoids Making Statement on Festival's Reaction to War in Gaza ‚ÄòCaught Stealing' Review: It's a Swing and a Miss for Darren Aronofsky's Grim Austin Butler-Starring NYC Crime Caper An official synopsis of the film reads, ‚ÄúThe Allies, led by the unyielding chief prosecutor, Robert H. Jackson (Michael Shannon), have the task of ensuring the Nazi regime answers for the unveiled horrors of the Holocaust while a US Army psychiatrist (Rami Malek) is locked in a dramatic psychological duel with former Reichsmarschall Herman G√∂ring (Russell Crowe).‚Äù ‚ÄúNuremberg‚Äù is the second film directed by Vanderbilt (after 2015's ‚ÄúTruth‚Äù), whose screenwriting credits include ‚ÄúZodiac,‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Amazing Spider-Man,‚Äù and three ‚ÄúScream‚Äù movies. Vanderbilt also wrote the script, which is adapted from Jack El-Hai's nonfiction book ‚ÄúThe Nazi and the Psychiatrist.‚Äù In addition to Malek, Crowe, and Shannon, the film stars Richard E. Grant, Leo Woodall, John Slattery, Mark O'Brien, Colin Hanks, Lydia Peckham, Wrenn Schmidt and Andreas Pietschmann. ‚ÄúNuremberg‚Äù was filmed in Budapest in 2024, with frequent Ridley Scott collaborator Dariusz Wolski serving as cinematographer. Richard Saperstein, Bradley J. Fischer, James Vanderbilt, William Sherak, and Walden Media's Frank Smith, Benjamin Tappan, and Cherilyn Hawrysh, Istv√°n Major, and George Freeman produced the film. Jack El-Hai, Brooke Saperstein, Annie Saperstein, Beau Turpin, W. Porter Payne, Jr., Paul Neinstein, and Sz√©chenyi Funds G√©za Deme and Tam√°s Hajnal also serve as executive producers. Sony Pictures Classics will release ‚ÄúNuremberg‚Äù in theaters on Friday, November 7 following its world premiere in the Gala Presentations section of the Toronto International Film Festival. Trump Rages About "Rumor" That NBC Extended Seth Meyers' Contract
Source: Deadline    Published: 2025-08-27 13:56:00

By Ted Johnson Political Editor Even as traditional TV networks grapple with balkanized audiences and relevance at a time of YouTube and so many options, Donald Trump still has his attention on his most persistent broadcast critics. Late on Tuesday, the president wrote on Truth Social, ‚ÄúThere is a sick rumor going around that Fake News NBC extended the contract of one of the least talented Late Night television hosts out there, Seth Meyers. He has no Ratings, Talent, or Intelligence, and the Personality of an insecure child. So, why would Fake News NBC extend this dope's contract. I don't know, but I'll definitely be finding out!!!‚Äù Related Stories News FCC Chair Tells Google To Get Deal Done In YouTube TV-Fox Carriage Fight; YouTube Responds - Update News Donald Trump Is Asked By Reporter About Taylor Swift-Travis Kelce Engagement: "I Wish Them A Lot Of Luck" Meyers, who has hosted NBC's Late Night for more than a decade, signed a new contract last year that extended his deal through 2028. Watch on Deadline A spokesperson for Late Night with Seth Meyers said that they had no comment. Trump's cryptic warning that he would ‚Äúdefinitely be finding out‚Äù about why the contract was extended is his latest attempt to place pressure on major media companies over their content. It's also not the first time that Trump has called out Meyers. In January, just before taking office again, Trump threatened that Comcast, the parent company of NBC, should ‚Äúpay a BIG price‚Äù for featuring the show, calling it an ‚Äúin-kind‚Äù contribution to ‚Äúthe Radical Left Democrat Party.‚Äù Trump, though, appeared to be conflating the FCC‚Äòs equal time rule with the fairness doctrine. The equal time rule requires broadcasters who feature candidates to provide airtime to rivals if requested. But there is a ‚Äúbona fide‚Äù news exemption to the equal time rule, one that the FCC has extended to late night talk and other infotainment shows. Meyers' show would fall into the category if he had featured a candidate, but he did not last night, nor did he in January. If it was just Meyers expressing a political point of view, which he does night after night, the network would not be obligated to present other sides. That's because the FCC did away with the Fairness Doctrine in the 1980s. That policy mandated that broadcasters provide a diversity of viewpoints. Once it was repealed, it helped enable figures like Rush Limbaugh to emerge as leading voices on talk radio, as stations were no longer obligated to provide alternative views on important issues. That said, Trump's FCC chairman, Brendan Carr, has seemingly adopted a de facto Fairness Doctrine when reviewing proposed mergers before the agency. He trumpeted Skydance's commitment to provide a diversity of viewpoints at CBS following the FCC's approval of the company's merger with Paramount Global. But there are doubts that such commitments, even it comes down to it, are even enforceable. Just days before the FCC approval, CBS announced that it was cancelling The Late Show with Stephen Colbert, hosted by another Trump critic. The network cited financial reasons as the economics of late night have shifted. Meanwhile, another Paramount show, South Park, has been scathing in its satire of Trump. But that show runs on Comedy Central, a cable channel largely outside the bounds of FCC enforcement. Get our Breaking News Alerts and Keep your inbox happy. Comments On Deadline Hollywood are monitored. So don't go off topic, don't impersonate anyone, and don't get your facts wrong. The attempt of a dictator to silence the media continues For those of you who still use the word wannabe, as I used to, need to realize the dictatorship is here. Just this morning saw where DOT is taking over a Union Station. Still trying to shake down the mainstream media, while distracting from the ongoing Epstein scandal and his illegal attempts to oust Jerome Powell from the Federal Reserve. Meanwhile, price of eggs and gasoline are soaring again. ‚ÄúHe has no Ratings, Talent, or Intelligence, and the Personality of an insecure child.‚Äù Lol, he's talking about himself? Certainly fits Trump to a ‚ÄúT‚Äù. If only the Orange Wannabe Dictator was as tough on Vladimir Putin as he is on late-night talk show hosts. This country is in deep trouble. ‚ÄòHarry Potter' Director Chris Columbus Says Photos Of Hagrid From HBO Series Left Him Asking: ‚ÄúWhat's The Point?‚Äù
Source: Deadline    Published: 2025-08-27 13:45:00

By Jake Kanter International Investigations Editor Chris Columbus has said pictures of Hagrid from the set of HBO‚Äòs Harry Potter series have left him wondering why J.K. Rowling‚Äòs books are being adapted again. Columbus was central to establishing the hit movie series after directing Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone and Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets with a cast including Daniel Radcliffe, Rupert Grint, and Emma Watson. Appearing on The Rest Is Entertainment podcast, Columbus said he was somewhat baffled by the HBO TV series remake, which is currently shooting in the UK. Related Stories News 'The Rehearsal' May Have Actually Helped Find A Solution To Pilot's Mental Health Issues, After All Reviews 'The Thursday Murder Club' Review: A Veteran Cast Including Helen Mirren And Pierce Brosnan, Bestselling Books And A Mystery Means Netflix Has A New Franchise The Home Alone helmer said he had seen unofficial photos of the HBO series filming in London and was struck by how similar Rubeus Hagrid's costume and body double were to those used for Robbie Coltrane. Hagrid is played by Nick Frost in the TV series. Watch on Deadline ‚ÄúSo, I'm seeing these photographs ‚Ä¶ and he's wearing the exact same costume that we designed for Hagrid. Part of me was like: What's the point?‚Äù Columbus said. ‚ÄúI thought everything was going to be different, but it's more of the same. It's all going to be the same.‚Äù He continued: ‚ÄúIt's very flattering for me, because I'm like, that's exactly the Hagrid costume that we designed. So, part of it is really exciting, so I'm excited to see what they're going to do with it. Part of it is sort of deja vu all over again.‚Äù Columbus, who recently described Rowling's transgender views as ‚Äúvery sad,‚Äù added that he was not envious that HBO would be able to adapt the Harry Potter books on a bigger canvas than the movies. ‚ÄúJealous? No,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt's time to move on. I've always had issues with [the] idea of franchise. I feel like I've done it ‚Ä¶ I'm really proud of those films, the first three that I was involved with, and I'm moving on.‚Äù Columbus is currently promoting Netflix movie The Thursday Murder Club, which is based on the books of Richard Osman. Osman also hosts The Rest Is Entertainment podcast. Get our Breaking News Alerts and Keep your inbox happy. Comments On Deadline Hollywood are monitored. So don't go off topic, don't impersonate anyone, and don't get your facts wrong. Comment Name Email Website Œî The expectation for a reboot of a successful franchise is that it will put its own spin on what preceded it. If the costume design and sets are replicated verbatim then it's little more than what most believe it already is for Warner Bros.: a cash grab. This series has the potential to be as much of a misfire for Warner Bros. as ‚ÄúThe Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power‚Äù has been for Amazon. ‚ÄúWhat's the point?‚Äù Draw more millions out of the franchise? It's really not that hard to understand. JK needs more money to fund her hate campaigns against trans people I guess. So what he is claiming is that he designed Hagrids costume without any consideration to the books and Christ just got magically lucky with the design? If it is based off the book, of course there is going to be similarities. Hagrids look is similar to how he is described in the books. This guy is pompous and is essentially saying the books are copying his design. If you're going to reboot a series put your own spin on it. When Michael Gambon replaced Richard Harris after Harris' death, they made distinctive changes to the costume design to distinguish his Dumbledore from Harris'. Whether it's ‚ÄúDune‚Äù, ‚ÄúThe Addams Family‚Äù, ‚ÄúStar Trek‚Äù or even ‚ÄúLost in Space‚Äù, there are constants that carry over from one version to the next but each iteration separates itself visually from the others. Otherwise, as Columbus stated, what's the point? He's not wrong. But it lacks any self-awareness of his own lack of imagination with his ‚Äúadaptations.‚Äù Costume and look SHOULD be the same‚Ä¶ The changes should be the addition of book material that got cut from the movies. No one wants change for the sake of change. But adding plots and scenes that were cut will be an enjoyable thing BUT only if they stay book accurate and keep all the things that the movies had to cut for time sake. Source: Billboard    Published: 2025-08-27 13:22:44

Wednesday's (Aug. 27) podcast will feature a behind-the-scenes "Swift debrief" of the singer's record-setting appearance two weeks ago. By Gil Kaufman Jason Kelce could not be more psyched for his future sister-in-law. The voluble ex NFL great hopped on his socials on Tuesday night (Aug. 26) ‚Äî just hours after Taylor Swift announced that she was engaged to his younger brother Travis Kelce ‚Äî to enthusiastically congratulate the couple and share some special news about this week's New Heights podcast. ‚ÄúWelcome back to another episode of New Heights,‚Äù Jason said in the video in which he appeared alone in his home studio. ‚ÄúUnfortunately, it probably won't be as good as the last episode of New Heights, where we set our own records, we set podcasting records, we set a Guinness Book of World Records,‚Äù he gushed about Swift's record-shattering appearance on the previous episode of the sports podcast he co-hosts with Travis that increased the show's female viewership by more than 600%. Trending on Billboard ‚ÄúThanks to the one and only Taylor Swift for hopping on and deciding to talk with two complete idiots that don't know anything about the music industry,‚Äù he added about Swift's two-hour chat, in which she discussed her love story with Travis, announced her 12th studio album, The Life of a Showgirl and described the emotional moment she found out she'd gotten her masters back. Self-deprecatingly promising that the bar will be ‚Äúmuch lower‚Äù this week, Jason had to address the ‚Äúone piece of gigantic‚Äù news that broke after they recorded the new episode on Monday, which is Travis' one day off as he prepares to start his 13th NFL season. ‚ÄúSo he is not here to address this himself, but we felt necessary as a team here at New Heights to get together and send Travis and a giant congratulations for being engaged!!!,‚Äù Jason shouted as he and the show's staff whooped it up in celebration. ‚ÄúThe proposal heard 'round the world!!! F‚Äìk yeah!‚Äù Among the many A-listers and fellow musicians honoring the couple's news, the Kelce brothers' alma mater, the University of Cincinnati, posted a congratulations on the scoreboard at Nippert Stadium. ‚ÄúHey @killatrav, no pressure but we can get you a GREAT deal on an historic, picturesque wedding venue,‚Äù the team wrote using Travis' social handle. But that's not all. Jason also revealed that Wednesday's new episode will be a ‚Äúbehind-the-scenes look at how our episode with @taylorswift13 came together.‚Äù The BTS episode will post at 9:30 a.m. ET on Wednesday. Chat Pile and Hayden Pedigo Announce Album, Share Video for New Song: Watch
Source: Pitchfork    Published: 2025-08-27 13:16:46

Noise rockers Chat Pile have joined forces with the fingerpicking guitarist Hayden Pedigo for an unlikely collaborative album. In the Earth Again springs from the Oklahoma City DIY scene in which both artists operate (Pedigo is a Texas transplant) and arrives October 31 via the Computer Students label. Watch the Riley Stearns‚Äìdirected video for the first single, ‚ÄúRadioactive Dreams,‚Äù below, and scroll down to check out Malcolm Byers' album cover art and both artists' tour dates. Pedigo said in a press release, ‚ÄúWe all wanted to avoid the downfall you see in a lot of collab records.‚Äù He continued, ‚ÄúWe didn't want this record to either end up primarily sounding like one of us more than the other.‚Äù Chat Pile bassist Stin added, ‚ÄúEvery decision made was in support of each other's ideas and making sure that everything we did was in service of a greater vision.‚Äù In the Earth Again: 01 Outside02 Demon Time03 Never Say Die!04 Behold a Pale Horse05 The Magic of the World06 Fission/Fusion07 The Matador08 I Got My Own Blunt to Smoke09 Radioactive Dreams10 Inside11 A Tear for Lucas Chat Pile: 10-09 San Francisco, CA - The Fillmore #10-10 Los Angeles, CA - The Fonda Theatre #10-11 Los Angeles, CA - The Fonda Theatre #10-13 Mesa, AZ - Nile Theater #10-16 Oklahoma City, OK - Tower Theatre #10-17 Austin, TX - Emo's #10-18 Dallas, TX - The Echo Lounge & Music Hall #10-19 Houston, TX - White Oak Music Hall - Downstairs #10-21 Tampa, FL - The Orpheum #10-22 Orlando, FL - The Beacham #10-24 Charlottesville, VA - The Jefferson Theater #10-25 Baltimore, MD - Baltimore Soundstage #10-26 Washington, DC - 9:30 Club #10-28 Brooklyn, NY - Brooklyn Steel #10-29 Philadelphia, PA - Theatre of Living Arts #10-31 Boston, MA - Paradise Rock Club #11-01 Boston, MA - Paradise Rock Club # # with Fleshwater All products featured on Pitchfork are independently selected by our editors.
