The story of a NH alien abduction is set to become a feature film
Source: New Hampshire Public Radio    Published: 2025-08-27 16:54:00

New Hampshire is famous for two incidents in the 1960s involving UFOs. One is known as The Exeter Incident, when a hitchhiker and other witnesses say they saw a large flashing object in the sky. Another supposedly took place in the North Country, where Barney and Betty Hill of Portsmouth say they were abducted by aliens. Toby Ball is an author and host of the podcast ‚ÄúStrange Arrivals‚Äù about the Hills' experience and UFO folklore. The podcast is now being developed for a feature film with Demi Moore and Colman Domingo. This Thursday, he will be talking about the podcast and its transition to the big screen at Stratham's Wiggin Memorial Library. He spoke with NHPR's Rick Ganley about why the Hills' experience fascinates people to this day. Some people are familiar with the Hill story, but I just learned some Granite Staters don't know about this incident at all. Remind us who Betty and Barney Hill were. So Betty and Barney Hill were an interracial couple who lived in Portsmouth. The actual abduction ‚Äì supposed abduction ‚Äì took place in 1961. The Hills were both prominent in civil rights work in the Seacoast area during that time. But in 1961, they had gone on a trip. They had gone to Niagara Falls, Toronto, Montreal. On their way back from Montreal, they passed across the border near Colebrook and ended up driving through Franconia Notch on their way back to Portsmouth. It was in Franconia Notch and just past it that they had this supposed UFO encounter. In this encounter they said they were abducted, no? Yes they did. So it's interesting, at first they remembered seeing a UFO in a couple of different places in Franconia Notch and then further down by Indian Head. And then they felt as though they'd lost a couple hours of time. They arrived home a couple hours later than they were expecting to. And it wasn't until a couple of years later when they underwent hypnosis with this psychiatrist, Doctor Benjamin Simon, down in Boston ‚Äì he put them through regression, hypnosis. And Betty in particular, but Barney as well, suddenly had these memories of being sort of deflected off of the road that they were on, driving down a side road, running into a group of aliens brought aboard a flying saucer and subjected to medical exams before being returned and then continuing on their drive. So they didn't really know about that part of it for another two and a half years. What do you think happened? I don't know. I'm a skeptic in that I don't believe that they were actually abducted by aliens. But I think one of the reasons why this story has so much staying power is that there's not an easy answer to that question of what happened. In my podcast, I lay out several different factors that could have contributed to the overall sense that it had happened. They were driving while very fatigued. People have pointed out that Jupiter was very bright. They [drove] through Franconia Notch ‚Äì there's a light on top of Cannon Mountain. There's a whole bunch of these kinds of things that if you're fatigued and your anxiety level is high, can all kind of build into this narrative of, "There's something following us." I don't think they were actually abducted by aliens. Why do you think these stories of UFOs have such a hold on us? The Betty and Barney Hill story ‚Äì one of the things I think is really interesting about that is that it has really been sort of the template for alien abduction stories going forward. It's a lot of being taken from places that are fairly remote. The modern UFO age started in 1947 basically with a famed sighting up in Washington state, and then the Roswell supposed crash. After World War Two with the atomic bomb and other things that were going on technologically and people trying to come to terms with that, and then also desiring a sense of wonder and sort of melding those two together with the idea that these things with great technology ‚Äì technology beyond our understanding ‚Äì are coming to visit and ponder that there's more to the universe than what we encounter in our daily lives. NHPR is nonprofit and independent. We rely on readers like you to support the local, national, and international coverage on this website. Your support makes this news available to everyone. Give today. A monthly donation of $5 makes a real difference.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Republican leader's call to civil war shows extent of South Dakota's conspiracy infection
Source: South Dakota Searchlight    Published: 2025-08-27 14:44:51

State Rep. Brandei Schaefbauer, R-Aberdeen, speaks on the South Dakota House floor on Jan. 17, 2024. (Makenzie Huber/South Dakota Searchlight) In recent years it felt like the rest of the world was going crazy. There were conspiracy theories about the weirdest things: Barack Obama's birth certificate, the existence of a deep state that secretly controls the federal government, Donald Trump's supposed fight against a Satanic group of child molesters. Surely, these theories sprang from the cities where the friction of daily life in such confined quarters led people to believe the oddest things. Out here on the prairie, where there's plenty of room to roam, we seemed immune to those ideas. We seemed safe from conspiracy theories. Those days are over, if they ever existed. For me, the first hint that South Dakotans could be just as addled as the rest of the nation came in 2022. In one of the first commentaries ever published by South Dakota Searchlight, the writer described how he tried and tried to get secretary of state candidate Monae Johnson to admit that she believed the 2020 election was stolen from Donald Trump. He likened her artful dodging of his questions to trying to nail Jell-O to a tree. The trouble with Monae Johnson and Jell-O As a story, an election denier running for an office that oversees elections had a certain man bites dog quality to it. As an indication of what was to come, having a Republican candidate for statewide office embrace a conspiracy theory was just the tip of the iceberg. In 2023 the Legislature considered House Concurrent Resolution 6006 that called for the fair treatment of the Jan. 6, 2021, defendants who besieged the United States Capitol. Sponsored by Rep. Phil Jensen, a Rapid City Republican, the resolution was based on the conspiracy theory that those prisoners endured inhumane conditions; were subjected to cruel and unusual punishment; and were deprived of adequate food, medical care and access to religious services and attorneys. Concurrent resolutions don't have the weight of law, but are a reflection of the mood of the Legislature. The House State Affairs Committee wasn't in the mood, defeating the resolution 12-0. That doesn't change the fact that an elected representative sought to give a conspiracy theory legislative legitimacy. Since President Trump pardoned the insurrectionists, don't be surprised if a new resolution comes along, asking for reparations for the Jan. 6 ‚Äúpatriots.‚Äù Meanwhile, the conspiracy theory that the 2020 election was somehow stolen from President Trump caused a flurry of activity in South Dakota as ‚Äúelection integrity‚Äù backers made life miserable for county commissions across the state and pressured lawmakers to do more to make sure that the state's already squeaky clean elections were beyond reproach. In effect, a conspiracy theory has led to an unneeded movement that still has momentum. The level to which conspiracy theories have been accepted among elected leaders in this state can be found in an episode of the Ken Matthews podcast, which was called out for criticism on the South Dakota War College website. In that episode, Matthews interviewed Aberdeen Rep. Brandei Schaefbauer, a Republican majority whip in the House. In the last legislative session, Schaefbauer sponsored House Concurrent Resolution 6009, which sought to have the attorney general file a lawsuit against China to seek damages related to the COVID-19 pandemic. New commentary delivered to you: Sign up for our free newsletter. China, however, isn't the only pandemic culprit, as Schaefbauer told Matthews. Referencing the former director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, Anthony Fauci, Schaefbauer said, ‚ÄúHe should be on death row for killing millions and millions of people.‚Äù She also had something to say about the way the Trump administration is handling the Jeffrey Epstein files, which have been the topic of conspiracy theories about underage girls provided to high-ranking officials. Schaefbauer said ‚Äúif something doesn't happen‚Äù to satisfy people calling for the Epstein files, ‚Äúthere is going to be, I believe, a revolt of the American people. Because they have, I mean, we have all been promised that something is going to happen, and we get this little, you know, give us this little nugget, and then it's a pacifier for us. Well, no, I think the way things are going ‚Äî people are so upset and they have nothing else to lose ‚Äî so why not let's just start, you know, a civil war again.‚Äù There you have it, a call to civil war by a leader in South Dakota's Republican Party. That almost makes Johnson's refusal to answer questions about who won the 2020 election seem quaint and harmless. by Dana Hess, South Dakota Searchlight August 27, 2025 by Dana Hess, South Dakota Searchlight August 27, 2025 In recent years it felt like the rest of the world was going crazy. There were conspiracy theories about the weirdest things: Barack Obama's birth certificate, the existence of a deep state that secretly controls the federal government, Donald Trump's supposed fight against a Satanic group of child molesters. Surely, these theories sprang from the cities where the friction of daily life in such confined quarters led people to believe the oddest things. Out here on the prairie, where there's plenty of room to roam, we seemed immune to those ideas. We seemed safe from conspiracy theories. Those days are over, if they ever existed. For me, the first hint that South Dakotans could be just as addled as the rest of the nation came in 2022. In one of the first commentaries ever published by South Dakota Searchlight, the writer described how he tried and tried to get secretary of state candidate Monae Johnson to admit that she believed the 2020 election was stolen from Donald Trump. He likened her artful dodging of his questions to trying to nail Jell-O to a tree. The trouble with Monae Johnson and Jell-O As a story, an election denier running for an office that oversees elections had a certain man bites dog quality to it. As an indication of what was to come, having a Republican candidate for statewide office embrace a conspiracy theory was just the tip of the iceberg. In 2023 the Legislature considered House Concurrent Resolution 6006 that called for the fair treatment of the Jan. 6, 2021, defendants who besieged the United States Capitol. Sponsored by Rep. Phil Jensen, a Rapid City Republican, the resolution was based on the conspiracy theory that those prisoners endured inhumane conditions; were subjected to cruel and unusual punishment; and were deprived of adequate food, medical care and access to religious services and attorneys. Concurrent resolutions don't have the weight of law, but are a reflection of the mood of the Legislature. The House State Affairs Committee wasn't in the mood, defeating the resolution 12-0. That doesn't change the fact that an elected representative sought to give a conspiracy theory legislative legitimacy. Since President Trump pardoned the insurrectionists, don't be surprised if a new resolution comes along, asking for reparations for the Jan. 6 ‚Äúpatriots.‚Äù Meanwhile, the conspiracy theory that the 2020 election was somehow stolen from President Trump caused a flurry of activity in South Dakota as ‚Äúelection integrity‚Äù backers made life miserable for county commissions across the state and pressured lawmakers to do more to make sure that the state's already squeaky clean elections were beyond reproach. In effect, a conspiracy theory has led to an unneeded movement that still has momentum. The level to which conspiracy theories have been accepted among elected leaders in this state can be found in an episode of the Ken Matthews podcast, which was called out for criticism on the South Dakota War College website. In that episode, Matthews interviewed Aberdeen Rep. Brandei Schaefbauer, a Republican majority whip in the House. In the last legislative session, Schaefbauer sponsored House Concurrent Resolution 6009, which sought to have the attorney general file a lawsuit against China to seek damages related to the COVID-19 pandemic. New commentary delivered to you: Sign up for our free newsletter. China, however, isn't the only pandemic culprit, as Schaefbauer told Matthews. Referencing the former director of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, Anthony Fauci, Schaefbauer said, ‚ÄúHe should be on death row for killing millions and millions of people.‚Äù She also had something to say about the way the Trump administration is handling the Jeffrey Epstein files, which have been the topic of conspiracy theories about underage girls provided to high-ranking officials. Schaefbauer said ‚Äúif something doesn't happen‚Äù to satisfy people calling for the Epstein files, ‚Äúthere is going to be, I believe, a revolt of the American people. Because they have, I mean, we have all been promised that something is going to happen, and we get this little, you know, give us this little nugget, and then it's a pacifier for us. Well, no, I think the way things are going ‚Äî people are so upset and they have nothing else to lose ‚Äî so why not let's just start, you know, a civil war again.‚Äù There you have it, a call to civil war by a leader in South Dakota's Republican Party. That almost makes Johnson's refusal to answer questions about who won the 2020 election seem quaint and harmless. South Dakota Searchlight is part of States Newsroom, a nonprofit news network supported by grants and a coalition of donors as a 501c(3) public charity. South Dakota Searchlight maintains editorial independence. Contact Editor Seth Tupper for questions: info@southdakotasearchlight.com. Our stories may be republished online or in print under Creative Commons license CC BY-NC-ND 4.0. We ask that you edit only for style or to shorten, provide proper attribution and link to our website. AP and Getty images may not be republished. Please see our republishing guidelines for use of any other photos and graphics. Dana Hess spent more than 25 years in South Dakota journalism, editing newspapers in Redfield, Milbank and Pierre. He's retired and lives in Brookings, working occasionally as a freelance writer. We seek to serve the public interest with accuracy, fairness, insight and civility. We're part of States Newsroom, the nation's largest state-focused nonprofit news organization. Aliens Might Be Chatting With the Planet Next Door. We Could Listen In.
Source: Popular Mechanics    Published: 2025-08-27 12:30:00

Transmissions between Earth and our own spacecraft could tell us where to look for potential alien transmissions. Here's what you'll learn when you read this story: Even the most sophisticated radio arrays have not yet detected any signals that could have possibly been beamed through space by aliens. But maybe we just need to approach the search for technosignatures differently. Maybe aliens have no interest in phoning Earth, and would rather transmit message to their own probes orbiting nearby planets. Whether aliens have any desire to explore space like we do is unknown. They might be content kicking back on whatever passes for a hammock on their own planets. But it is hard to believe that (if anything remotely like us exists out in the cosmos) there wouldn't be at least one form of intelligent life that would want to see what lies beyond their home turf. Whether they whiz through the void in flying saucers or starships is debatable, but they might be sending and receiving signals from their own contraptions launched into space to explore their cosmic neighborhoods‚Äîmuch like we do. Astronomer and astrophysicist Pinchen Fan thinks that intelligent aliens might be doing the same thing we are and communicating with probes and spacecraft similar to NASA's Deep Space Network (DSN). It might be possible to pick up on their transmissions if we can compare them to incoming and outgoing messages on our planet, so we at least know what to look for. This is not the first time researchers have investigated this idea, but this team had a very particular focus. Fan wanted to know what a hypothetical observer from a distant planet would see through their hypothetical telescope if they were tracking transmissions to and from Earth. Some planets or other objects might block transmissions. Others, like Mars, would not block them completely‚Äîand aliens should be able to catch that. Planetary conjunctions, when two planets directly align with one another in orbit, are ideal opportunities for this. ‚ÄúIn the case of Mars, we find a species that is able to observe the Solar System for radio emission during an Earth-Mars conjunction in the past twenty years would have had a 77% chance of observing during one of our transmissions,‚Äù Fan said in a study recently published in The Astrophysical Journal. Operated by NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL), the Deep Space Network consists of three ground-based facilities in California, Spain and Australia that are capable of two-way communication with spacecraft, sending commands and receiving information. These sites were strategically chosen so there are no interruptions to communication as Earth rotates. If a spacecraft ventures too far for one site to pick up what it is doing, another site can easily receive the signal and continue communications. By poring through DSN logs, Fan and his research team were able to connect their findings to the location of a spacecraft or space telescope at a specific time so they could figure out when and in what direction radio communications were beamed from Earth. Most radio signals were aimed at spacecraft on or near Mars (which should hardly be a surprise, with all the attention the planet has been awarded since Perseverance and Ingenuity landed in 2021). Transmissions to Mars‚Äîas opposed to other planets in the Solar System‚Äîalso have the greatest chance of being detected by extraterrestrials. If we switch around the point of view and position ourselves as observers, there should be some planets between which we have an especially high chance of intercepting transmissions. Fan is confident his research prioritizes which objects to look out for. The most powerful transmissions coming from humans (including those from the DSN) tend to be within a few degrees of the ecliptic plane, or the imaginary flat plane created by Earth's orbit, and similar alien transmissions would likely also line up as such. There may also be preferable times for transmission detection. DSN transmissions have peaked at certain times during Earth's orbit‚Äîespecially conjunctions between Earth and the Sun. Aliens using the same strategy might experience a peak in transmissions during their own planet's conjunctions with their star. ‚ÄúAs humankind broadens its presence in the Solar System, sustained transmissions to other planets would further intensify the concentration of strong transmissions along the ecliptic plane,‚Äù said Fan. ‚ÄúOur analysis underscores the value of using humanity's own DSN as a model for how an early-phase spacefaring civilization might transmit and how we might detect it.‚Äù Whether the planets we end up focusing on for SETI investigations will be the planets with other creatures on them is unknown. But if we're lucky, we just might end up eavesdropping on ET phoning... somewhere. Elizabeth Rayne is a creature who writes. Her work has appeared in Popular Mechanics, Ars Technica, SYFY WIRE, Space.com, Live Science, Den of Geek, Forbidden Futures and Collective Tales. She lurks right outside New York City with her parrot, Lestat. When not writing, she can be found drawing, playing the piano or shapeshifting. Two Men Were Fixing an Antenna in New Jersey‚Äîand Accidentally Discovered Proof of the Big Bang Is This Evidence of Life Beyond Earth? The Mission to Defend Earth From a Killer Asteroid Pop Mech Explains the Universe Do You Know How Moons and Planets Are Different? Interstellar Comet Might Be 7 Billion Years Old A Meteorite Older than Earth Crashed Into a House This Odd Galaxy Defies Cosmic Evolution The Best Star Projectors for Stargazing at Home The Best Telescopes Betelgeuse Has Been Hiding Something Big Every Image From the Webb Space Telescope (So Far) A Part of Hearst Digital Media We may earn commission from links on this page, but we only recommend products we back. ¬©2025 Hearst Magazine Media, Inc. All Rights Reserved.
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Spooky Science: Paranormal researchers talk Annabelle, new 'Conjuring' film
Source: dnronline.com    Published: 2025-08-27 09:15:00

Sun and clouds mixed. High 73F. Winds NW at 5 to 10 mph.. A few passing clouds. Low 47F. Winds light and variable. Updated: August 27, 2025 @ 1:14 pm Pennsylvania paranormal writer Maxim Furek was supposed to interview Dan Rivera, the primary handler of the supposedly possessed Annabelle doll, on July 14. But the interview never happened. Furek later learned that Rivera, 54, passed away unexpectedly at his Gettysburg hotel room on July 13, the day before the interview was scheduled to take place. Although Furek did see Rivera in Gettysburg that weekend and discuss shared connections, including the fact that they both knew paranormal pioneers Ed and Lorraine Warren, Furek wanted to do more than just talk. Furek wanted to interview Rivera, who was in Gettysburg for the ‚ÄúDevils on the Run‚Äù Tour, for Furek's book on the Smurl Haunting, which the Warrens had investigated. That book, ‚ÄúThe Smurl Haunting: When Ed and Lorraine Came to Town,‚Äù was published this month. The Smurl Hauntings are the basis of the most recent Conjuring movie, ‚ÄúThe Conjuring: Last Rites.‚Äù During the Devils on the Run Tour, which continues through October, people can see the Annabelle doll and other objects from the Warrens' Occult Museum ‚Äî for a price. ‚ÄúThey made money on this thing. What I believe the number was 1,240 people over two days, paying $40 a piece,‚Äù said Furek of the number of people who were in Gettysburg to see the doll for themselves. The paranormal community is divided over how the doll should be handled and if it should go on tour at all. Some believe that it never should have left the Warren's Occult Museum in Connecticut. There is also controversy because the home has recently been purchased by comedian Matt Rife and Elton Castee, who hunt ghosts and post videos about it on YouTube. When Furek saw the doll in Gettysburg, he said it was kept in a wooden box with a glass window that allowed people to view it. The box features three crosses etched into it, representing the Holy Trinity of Father, Son, and Holy Spirit. The case's wood is infused with both holy water and holy oil. Attached to the case inside is the Lord's Prayer. Though the coroner said the doll handler's death was not suspicious, not everyone in the paranormal community is convinced, Furek said. ‚ÄúThere are a lot of people in the paranormal community who believe there was a demonic presence that caused the death of Dan Rivera,‚Äù Furek said. The tour began in May of 2025 and made its way through spooky places in West Virginia, Texas, and Louisiana. Some strange and suspicious incidents were reported in cities where the Annabelle doll was on tour, including Gettysburg. A few days after Annabelle arrived in New Orleans, the 165-year-old Nottoway Plantation, located nearby in White Castle, Louisiana, caught fire and was destroyed, sparking online conspiracy theories. Other unusual events also occurred, such as a statewide 911 outage that happened while Annabelle was in Pennsylvania. Some people speculate that the doll may also be responsible for that. ‚ÄúYou want to call it a strange coincidence,‚Äù Furek said. ‚ÄúThat's fine, but I mean, it seems that there are too many strange things happening surrounding this Annabelle doll that looks like Raggedy Ann, so I certainly can't explain it. I'm just looking for answers, but I'm as mystified as everybody else.‚Äù Others believe that bad luck can sometimes be a matter of chance. ‚ÄúOnce you start a string of power of suggestion like that, it's human nature to string it all together,‚Äù said Patrick, a paranormal investigator, who also co-owns the Museum of Haunted Objects in Gettysburg. ‚ÄúIf I had a heart attack tomorrow, I wouldn't want people to go around and say, ‚ÄòOh, he was testing a voodoo doll from Haiti or whatever. I would want people to remember me for who I was and not that.'‚Äù Can a doll be haunted? Furek, who has written other books about paranormal events in Pennsylvania, including ‚ÄúCoal Region HooDoo: Paranormal Tales from Inside the Pit,‚Äù said that he believes objects can be haunted. However, when he saw Annabelle on tour, he didn't see any evidence of anything particularly unusual happening. ‚ÄúIn the realm of the paranormal, we believe that people can possess places, people, or things,‚Äù he said. However, Furek admits that Rivera himself wasn't afraid of the doll. ‚ÄúDan was not afraid of the Annabelle doll,‚Äù Furek said. ‚ÄúHe believed that, as a Christian, he was on firm ground.‚Äù According to Furek, Rivera was a former Methodist who converted to Catholicism. The Warrens were also Catholic, and Furek is as well. The story of the Annabelle doll is told in several films that are part of the wildly successful Conjuring universe, which are based on some of the Warrens' most famous cases. Ed Warren was a demonologist, and Lorraine Warren was a light trance medium, meaning she believed she could connect with spirits while in a trance, but she still remembered what happened afterward. James Madison University Associate Professor Lindsey Harvell-Bowman, an expert on death, death anxiety and suicide prevention, said one of the reasons people love these films so much is that they feel real. ‚ÄúFeeling scared makes people feel alive ‚Äî I think that is why any horror film succeeds. But, specifically ‚ÄòThe Conjuring' franchise offers more reality than most horror films. The original film was based on a true story,‚Äù she said. Even if not all the details of the film are entirely accurate, they feel real. Because of that, she said, the movies can seem even scarier. ‚ÄúAnybody could get possessed or have a spirit take a liking to them ‚Äî so, patrons can imagine themselves in these situations, which makes it all the more scary ‚Äî and consequently, [they feel] all the more alive,‚Äù she said. One of the cases that the Warrens were called upon to investigate was the Annabelle doll case, which inspired multiple films in The Conjuring universe. The story behind the doll is that Donna's mother gave her the doll as a gift for her 28th birthday. In the films, the Annabelle doll is creepy and porcelain, but in real life, she's a plain Raggedy Ann doll. According to the story, after Donna put the doll on her bed, she noticed that it seemed to change positions. Then Donna and her roommate began finding parchment paper on the floor that had messages like ‚ÄúHelp us, help me.‚Äù The doll reportedly started appearing in different rooms. Then, according to the story, a male friend of Donna's was taking a nap, and he woke up feeling like he was being strangled. Reportedly, the doll appeared to be staring at him, and there were scratches on its upper chest. At first, the girls thought that someone might be breaking into their apartment, moving the doll, and leaving notes, but then they began to suspect that something more sinister was at work. The girls consulted a psychic who told them that a girl named Annabelle Higgins lived there and died at the age of 7. The psychic believed that Annabelle wanted to stay with them and be loved. So the girls showered the doll with energy. However, after things worsened, the Warrens were brought in. They believed the doll wasn't possessed but was being manipulated by an inhuman energy that wanted to possess a human. Others have a different theory. One of them is Chris McKinnell, the Warrens' grandson, who was vocally opposed to taking the Annabelle doll on tour. ‚ÄúMy grandparents, Ed and Lorraine Warren, dedicated their lives to helping people suffering from real and terrifying experiences. That work was never meant to be sensationalized. It was sacred, and it still is,‚Äù McKinnell said in a social media post made in May. McKinnell believes that, rather than being haunted, Annabelle is an egregore, which is created by collective energy. In this case, McKinnell believes that the egregore was created by the energy that Donna and her roommate poured into the doll. Some people question whether objects can be haunted at all. But Patrick, who co-owns the Museum of Haunted Objects in Gettysburg, is one of those people who thinks that they can be, though he doesn't come to that conclusion lightly. All the objects in his museum, with over 100 items, undergo rigorous testing. ‚ÄúI approach everything very scientifically,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd most of the time, I can figure out what it is. I got into this because people wanted a more scientific approach to it.‚Äù Patrick said he had been involved in the paranormal community for a long time and hadn't considered collecting haunted objects until he began collaborating with Johlene ‚ÄúSpooky‚Äù Riley, one of the museum's other co-owners. He said that about 20 years ago, Spooky started removing items from people's homes that ‚Äúthey deemed unwanted or were scared of or bad luck, even. And since then, I've traveled all over the world doing investigations and then housing them safely in an EM proof building.‚Äù ‚ÄúWe don't seek the items out anymore,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWhat happens typically, if something is from a famous haunt or paranormal area, say, for instance, if someone called us that had an item that was in a home that had an exorcism, if it's a highly known, you know, we'll be interested in taking a look at it,‚Äù he said. However, the museum also receives calls from random individuals who believe a less well-known object is haunted. Patrick said that once the museum has an item, the team gathers as much information about it as possible. Then they create a sterile environment around it and conduct a comprehensive battery of tests on it. These 19 tests look for electromagnetic frequencies, temperature changes, motion sensing, and disembodied voices, he said. ‚ÄúWe do a long list of tests on every single item, from EMF tests to recordings on multiple levels in a sterile environment,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúAnd if it's deemed that it's active, we'll put it in a museum. And if it's deemed it's active and dangerous, we'll put it in a containment unit and still put it in the museum in a containment area, but it'll still be public if we deem that we can't find anything wrong with it, or anything attached to it, a lot of times, we'll destroy it,‚Äù he said. Patrick believes that it's common for dolls to be haunted. ‚ÄúI'm a subscriber to the belief that energy doesn't just disappear,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt goes somewhere, and if you spend a lot of energy on a person, place, or thing, when you're gone, that energy might just stay with that person, place, or thing,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBelieving that, dolls are very, very special and unique to specific people, and people spend a lot of time with those items when they're young, and I do believe that a lot of that energy gets stored with them.‚Äù Patrick said he also receives numerous calls about chairs, jewelry, photographs, paintings, and urns. ‚ÄúSometimes, you just get those random things that were just in a really bad place for a long time, or something that someone has altered purposely, ritualistically,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThere's an endless supply of them out there, and people definitely don't want them, and they don't want to house them, and they're afraid to destroy them out of fear, so we house them for them.‚Äù Despite being around haunted objects, Patrick said he's usually not afraid. However, there was one time when he left a potentially haunted building. But he was younger then. ‚ÄúI don't really get too squeamish about anything anymore,‚Äù he said. He isn't religious himself and doesn't know whether things like sage and holy water are protective, but he does work with people who think they are. ‚ÄúI don't use that stuff personally,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI've never seen it not work, and I've never seen it work. I couldn't tell you for sure.‚Äù Though some have claimed that people have been hurt or killed after seeing the Annabelle doll, in Gettysburg, there have been no such claims, Patrick said. ‚ÄúI actually tell them every time they come through the door that we make sure that nothing's going to follow them home, and, if it does, to bring it back, because it's bad for business,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI like to keep everything where it's supposed to be. But we've never had that claim, so hopefully, that'll continue. Our goal is not to make people feel unsafe in their homes when they go home. We want them to have a good and entertaining experience, and then go home safe.‚Äù One object in the Museum of Haunted Objects that might make people feel unsafe is a doll, reportedly from Indonesia, that you can't look in the eye. According to the story, ‚ÄúIt took on the likeness of the owner, and then you would die,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThat doll was in a full-on Faraday cage behind another metal barrier.‚Äù Precautions like that help keep people safe. ‚ÄúYou don't touch it, you don't move it, you don't [take] photographs,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThere are no photographs because you wouldn't want to give a bunch of energy to anything. The safety of the public is number one.‚Äù However, another paranormal investigator, Jeff Santos of Virginia Paranormal Investigations, which investigates supposedly haunted places throughout Virginia as well as the surrounding states, doesn't believe the danger comes from the objects themselves. Santos, a Christian who lives in the Yorktown area, started his paranormal investigation team in 2008. He said that, in the years of conducting paranormal investigations, he has found no evidence that objects can be haunted. ‚ÄúI've never found any evidence of these objects actually being haunted,‚Äù he said. Santos believes that the real danger comes from fear. ‚ÄúI don't think that the ghost of a living person will go into an object,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI do think that there are demons that are always around, and they're going to act [on people's vulnerability and fear]. Demons will prey on your fear. Your faith is your shield. I think that the biggest thing is to make sure that your faith is strong. If someone has enough faith to walk up and see that doll, I think the person will be fine.‚Äù Santos doesn't believe that things like sage and mediums work. Instead, he believes in using Scripture. After seeing the power of Scripture, he said he ended up earning a Master of Divinity degree at Regent University, and he practices what he calls deliverance ministry. Deliverance ministry, Santos said, involves a process of closing the doorways ‚Äúthat demons can use to get into your life. The demon, the Devil, the greatest weapon is deception, and leading people to believe they don't exist. Demons are everywhere.‚Äù Santos said he liked The Conjuring movies, which he thought were well done, but he viewed them as fiction. ‚ÄúThey're very embellished from what actually happened; they're not all truth,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúThere's been some creative liberties taken there.‚Äù When the Warrens came to town Even before the press surrounding the Smurl House, locals were aware that it was haunted. ‚ÄúBefore I was born, my parents lived up in Pittston,‚Äù Santos said. ‚ÄúThey knew of the house and stuff. They said that the house was haunted before it was known.‚Äù Patrick said that the museum currently has an item from the Smurl House. ‚ÄúIt's a Smurl House mirror. We have one of the mirrors from that home, from that haunting. That mirror was already bound in a binding that we were told not to remove. When we tested that mirror, I tested that mirror with the binding attached to it.‚Äù Even bound, the mirror still gave off a 1.9 EMF rating, ‚Äúwhich is one of the highest things we've ever had. It also does have temperature changes around it, which suggests, in the paranormal community, a demonic presence.‚Äù The Smurl Haunting refers to paranormal events that were reportedly experienced by the Smurl family in West Pittston, Pennsylvania, from the mid-70s to the late 80s. ‚ÄúThey were experiencing things all the way back from the seventies, such as things moving and assaults going on in there, loud noises, a dog being thrown through the wall or into the wall, doors slamming, images showing up in mirrors, and we have one of the mirrors from that home,‚Äù he said. Furek said that the Smurl House was like the Pennsylvania version of what happened in Amityville, on Long Island. Patrick said that, from what he has seen of the Smurl Haunting, including the mirror, it appears to be a legitimate haunting. ‚ÄúUnfortunately, the Warrens have had a lot of bad publicity over the years, and a lot of their things, people don't believe, as far as people thinking they were conning, like con artists,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSo I don't know, I would have to investigate it myself. The mirror seemed legit. I checked off on the mirror. It came from that house. I would assume that something is going on with Annabelle because of all of the claims.‚Äù What many people don't know is that the Warrens didn't just come to West Pittston, Pennsylvania. They also visited the town of Bridgewater, an event mentioned in both the 1982 Ripples, the yearbook of Bridgewater College, and The Daily News-Record. However, they didn't come to Bridgewater to investigate haunted objects. They presented their work in a series of lectures at colleges and universities including Bridgewater College. According to the Daily News-Record, the event was held during Halloween week. Like Santos, Ed Warren told people not to open the door to demons by using a Ouija Board because it could cause problems. ‚ÄúIt doesn't have to come that night, but it will come,‚Äù Warren said. However, not all ghost hunters are convinced. One of them is Steven Klinger, one of the hosts of Slice of the Paranormal, a podcast where the hosts travel the country, try local pizza, and share information. ‚ÄúIt's a way to share history in the local paranormal community and not just what the ghost lore is,‚Äù he said. He views Ouija Boards as being harmless, though he feels like he's in the minority in the ghost community. ‚ÄúI would say that the majority of ghost hunters view Ouija boards as evil,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI do not. I think that inherently, Ouija boards are just a device used to communicate with the dead. Well, the same ghost hunters that tell you, ‚ÄòYou know Ouija boards are evil,' are also using a recorder to talk to the dead and get answers.‚Äù He said that people using recording devices to communicate with ghosts don't have any clearer idea of whom they are talking to than people playing the game. ‚ÄúI don't think Parker Brothers, who makes the game, has any more connection to Satan than Sony does for making the digital recorders,‚Äù he said. Klinger said that he thinks objects can be haunted, but he personally hasn't experienced any. However, he has been to places where he believes he has encountered ghosts. ‚ÄúAnnabelle's power, I think, might be because people give it that power,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúSo I think that the objects themselves could be haunted. I'm not a complete skeptic on that. I have not personally experienced that with any of the haunted objects.‚Äù Local haunts If you want to see a place that's supposedly haunted, you don't have to travel all the way up to Pennsylvania to do so. There are local haunts, and some paranormal researchers say that these places are the real deal. One of those is Cherie Breeden, who runs Lunar Paranormal of Virginia as well as being the director of the Miler-Kite Historical Society in Elkton. The Miller-Kite Museum served as Stonewall Jackson's headquarters during a Shenandoah Valley campaign in the Civil War. She said some people come to the investigations expecting them to be fake and leave freaked out when they realize they're not. Sometimes this is because ‚Äúthey didn't expect any of the stuff that happens to happen,‚Äù she said. This is a feeling that Breeden can relate to because ‚ÄúI ran out of my house the first time I experienced a voice on my recorder.‚Äù Breeden became interested in communicating with the dead to help solve crimes, and she has done so in several cases, including the Alexa Murphy and Samantha Clark case. In both of those cases, Breeden said she told police where to find the girls' bodies even though they had been missing for more than 10 years. Breeden, who has a special ability to connect with the spirit world, said she wants to use it in a meaningful way. ‚ÄúI do want to use these connections with the spirit world to help with things,‚Äù she said. One of the other things she does is utilize her abilities for local ghost investigations. One of her upcoming investigations will be Elkton Town Hall's fourth annual Spook Walk, hosted by Lunar Paranormal, which will take place from 6:30 to 8:30 p.m. on Oct. 25. Tickets will be available starting Monday for $35 each. She'll also do a sunset paranormal investigation at Swannanoa in Afton on Nov. 2 from 5 to 7:30 p.m. She and a frequent investigative partner, Dr. Donald Molnar, a Charlottesville-based medical doctor also known as The Haunted MD, will lead the investigation. She also leads investigations at the Miller-Kite Museum, including one she plans to do this fall. For information, go to lunarparanormalvirginia.com. Molnar began conducting paranormal investigations in 2012, first through Twisted Paranormal Society in Fishersville, until 2018, when he started doing them independently. Like many who are drawn to the paranormal, he says, ‚ÄúI've kind of had weird things happen all my life from my childhood till now.‚Äù Breeden said that the museum is more haunted than her historic home, which she also said is ‚Äúpretty haunted.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Miller-Kite Museum is off the charts,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúIt's haunted inside and out, nighttime and daytime.‚Äù Molnar agrees that the museum is likely haunted. ‚ÄúEvery time, I try to tell myself it's not,‚Äù he said, ‚ÄúI go there, and I find stuff.‚Äù Breeden also said that she believes that the New Market Battlefield is haunted. ‚ÄúWe have some amazing evidence from that place,‚Äù he said. In terms of her encounters with the unknown, Breeden said that she isn't afraid. ‚ÄúI don't choose to communicate with anything negative,‚Äù she said. If something seems negative, she said she ignores it and moves on. She said she believes that her faith will keep her safe. ‚ÄúI'm a firm believer in God,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúI have 100% faith that he has my back.‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Conjuring: Last Rites‚Äù comes out Sept. 5. Contact Lori D'Angelo at ldangelo@dnronline.com or 540-208-2623. Breeden {!--StartFragment--}{span data-olk-copy-source=‚ÄùMessageBody‚Äù}Miler-Kite Historical Society in Elkton. {/span} Cherie Breeden sits at the Miller-Kite Museum in Elkton. Breeden, who directs the Miller-Kite Historical Society and runs Lunar Paranormal Virginia, believes the museum is haunted. I can only speak for myself, but this doesn't appear to have any relevance to life in the Shenandoah Valley. WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


The mysterious 3I/Atlas revives fascination with alien encounters and abductions
Source: IOL    Published: 2025-08-27 05:16:54

Elizabeth Klarer wtih a bust of her intergalactic lover, Akon. Image: Independent Media archives As scientists try to make sense of 3I/Atlas - the mysterious object hurtling towards Earth - it's unleashed fears of an alien invasion and brought back to the surface numerous supposed alien abduction cases that have never been disproved. An American couple, Betty and Barney Hill, went to their deathbeds convinced they were abducted and probed by aliens and had their memories of the 1961 encounter erased. Closer to home, Elizabeth Klarer of the KwaZulu-Natal Midlands even wrote a book about her intergalactic romance with a starship commander who got her pregnant in 1959. These two alien abduction stories are among dozens that have resurfaced as people ponder whether there could be any truth behind their extraordinary experiences, now that 3I/Atlas - bigger than Mount Everest - hurtles toward Earth in a way scientists describe as "not natural". This image from NASA shows the fast-moving interstellar object that has got many to wonder about alien encounters that have been reported over the years. Image: Supplied / NASA The object is moving at a speed of 209 000 kph, and has no tail, a telltale sign astronomers say distinguishes it from a comet. It was first picked up by a telescope in Chile and then photographed by the Hubble Space Telescope a few weeks ago. This visitor is bigger, faster and behaves differently from the two previous visitors to our galaxy - Oumuamua and Borisov - and is shielded behind the sun as it hurtles in our general direction. Professor Avi Loeb of Harvard University thinks the visitor is unlikely to be a natural object and believes governments around the world should formulate a treaty so they know how to handle a possible hostile alien invasion. Klarer had no such negative thoughts. For her, it was all about peace, love and understanding - things she tried to convey from her lover from the planet Meton in the Alpha Centauri System, according to earlier reports by "Independent Media". Elizabeth Klarer's sketch of Akon, with whom she claimed to have had a child with, named Ayling. Image: Independent Media Archives Klarer, who was a meteorologist, claimed to have had the most intimate encounter with extraterrestrials, writing in her book "Beyond the Light Barrier", published in 1980, that she bore a son with her alien lover, Akon. Klarer claimed her sightings at what became known as Flying Saucer Hill were witnessed by a Zulu manager, Ladam, as well as her sister, May, on the family farm in Rosetta. Various articles in the "Sunday Tribune" over the years reported that on April 7, 1956, she visited the hilltop again after further reports from her family that Zulu workers had seen the "lightning bird" appear there again. This time, Akon took her aboard his scout ship, a craft some 18 m in diameter, before transporting her to the cigar-shaped mother ship. During the encounter, kisses were exchanged, and he told Klarer that she was a reincarnated Venusian and a long-lost soulmate. He further explained that they occasionally took women from Earth as partners, as the offspring strengthened their race. He also claimed that several Venusians were living among us. She was returned to the hilltop thereafter. In 1959, Klarer claimed she visited Meton with Akon, orbiting Proxima Centauri, where she gave birth to their son, Ayling, before returning to Earth because the planet's vibrations played havoc with her heart. Klarer's main thrust throughout her life, and in the pages of her book, she strived to convey a message of peace, love, understanding and environmentalism, which she credited to the superior wisdom of an advanced and immaculately utopian Venusian civilisation. Klarer often commemorated the April 7 anniversary of her union with Akon by returning to Flying Saucer Hill, sometimes aided by others as she grew frail. Her interstellar love story inspired a stage production, and Jimmy Neversink even penned a tune on the unexplained affair across the Universe. When this reporter covered Klarer's funeral in Pietermaritzburg in February 1994, her sisters expressed profound loss, but were also at peace now that her battle against scepticism had come to an end. One, however, twirled her index finger about her head, indicating that her youngest sibling may have had a mental health issue. Betty and Barney Hill claimed they were abducted by aliens in 1961 while returning home from a visit to Niagara Falls. Image: CNN Archives In the case of the Hills, hypnosis was used to try to make sense of what had happened to the New Hampshire couple on September 19, 1961. They were on their way home from a trip to Niagara Falls when they saw a string of bright lights in the sky. The couple claimed that they were rendered unconscious by a group of humanoids who approached them when Barney got out of the family car, armed with his pistol, soon after a craft, measuring 12 meters across, blocked their path. What they did recall was waking up not far from the car. Betty's smart court shoes had been badly scuffed on the toes, as though she had been dragged there. Both their watches had stopped and never ticked again. After the troubling incident, Betty drew a star map which closely resembles actual star placements which were only discovered by astronomers a decade later, indicating that their alleged abductors had come from Zeta Reticuli. Media coverage turned the Hills into celebrities, spawning a 1975 made-for-television film starring James Earl Jones and Estelle Parsons. Betty's subsequent dreams showed a strong correlation with details Barney shared under hypnosis. However, in both cases, there was never enough evidence to conclusively prove their abduction story, nor to disprove it as a mere fiction. Related Topics: An ominous interstellar object named 3I/Atlas is hurtling towards our solar system at astonishing speeds. What does this mean for Earth, and could it be a sign of extraterrestrial ‚Ä¶ Klarer gained fame and notoriety during the height of apartheid with her incredible claim that she was abducted by an alien from the foothills of the Drakensberg. Independent Online, popularly known as IOL, is one of South Africa's leading news and information websites bringing millions of readers breaking news and updates on Politics, Current Affairs, Business, Lifestyle, Entertainment, Travel, Sport, Motoring and Technology. Read more

Beyond alien abductions and mysterious vanishings: Did the mystery of Bermuda Triangle just get solved?
Source: The Times of India    Published: 2025-08-27 04:25:00

Rupali Ganguly's Top 10 Must-Have Ethnic Looks for the Festive Season 10 great habits to be happier in life, shared by Robin Sharma Taylor Swift's engagement: All about the ‚Çπ4.38 crore ring everyone's talking about Saree Glamour: Kajal Aggarwal's best saree looks The hidden cost of helicopter parenting Bigg Boss 19's Nehal Chudasama brings the glam in these pics Shraddha Srinath flaunts curls gracefully 8 ways to fake being rich with your outfit styling Bigg Boss Malayalam fame Ansiba Hassan's gorgeous looks In pics: Stunning looks of Raksha Holla
WORLD NATIONAL BUSINESS CRYPTOCURRENCY SCIENCE TECHNOLOGY HEALTH SOCCER TENNIS FORMULA_1 ENTERTAINMENT OTHER


Harvard scientist has doubled down on their claims a mysterious object in space is an alien UFO
Source: supercarblondie.com    Published: 2025-08-27 00:19:00

Space Published on Aug 27, 2025 at 4:19 AM (UTC+4) by Daisy Edwards Last updated on Aug 26, 2025 at 5:29 PM (UTC+4) Edited by Emma Matthews This controversial Harvard scientist has doubled down on their claims that a mysterious object in space is an alien UFO and not a natural phenomenon. In July 2025, astronomers spotted a fast-moving interstellar object, which they called 3I/Atlas, and it was heading towards our solar system. It's about to fly past Jupiter, Mars, and Venus later this year. Most of the community of astronomers had decided that the unidentified flying object was most likely a comet, ratgher than a UFO in the most basic of terms. However, one particular Harvard scientist is convinced that in fact, this discovery was actually aliens rather than a comet, and this isn't the first time he's done it. EXPLORE SBX CARS ‚Äì Supercar auctions starting soon powered by Supercar Blondie Last month, astronomers named a fast-moving interstellar object in space 3I/Atlas as it was heading into our solar system. The astronomers were tracking its journey past Jupiter, Mars, and Venus, and most of the scientific community has declared 3I/Atlas is just a normal comet. However, one Harvard Scientist thinks that this UFO isn't what everyone is saying it is. And that, opposed to a comet, it's actually an alien spaceship. Avi Loeb is an astrophysicist, and he decided that the light that was emanating from the ‚Äòcomet' was not sunlight reflecting off it, as was previously decided. But actually, it was light coming from inside the alien spaceship itself. This isn't the first time Loeb has caused controversy by declaring that an unidentified flying object could be an alien rather than a piece of space detritus. Back in 2017, the astrophysicist speculated that an interstellar object named Oumuamua might have been alien technology. Some of the space science community agree with Loeb's ideas because of the curious trajectory towards Earth that the object has been taking, and it's trying to dodge observation, which Loeb thinks is notably weird. If Loeb is right, then it won't be long until the aliens arrive. If he isn't, we'll have a couple more cool comet rocks to investigate ‚Äì it's a win-win! DISCOVER SBX CARS: The global premium car auction platform powered by Supercar Blondie # Tags - Alien, Space, UFO Daisy Edwards is a Content Writer at supercarblondie.com. Daisy has more than five years' experience as a qualified journalist, having graduated with a History and Journalism degree from Goldsmiths, University of London and a dissertation in vintage electric vehicles. Daisy specializes in writing about cars, EVs, tech and luxury lifestyle. When she's not writing, she's at a country music concert or working on one of her many unfinished craft projects.
